lt: b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15606 / January 5, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. M.T.L. INTERNATIONAL FINANCE, INC.,\r     EQUITY ACTION PARTNERS, INC., JOHN K. ROBINSON, LEON HOWARD, AND HARRY\r     WALKER, 96 Civ. 7412 (U.S.D.C., S.D.N.Y.) (RWS)\r\r          A federal grand jury in St. Louis has charged Leon J. Howard, Jr., and\r     John K. Robinson with twenty-seven counts of conspiracy, wire fraud,\r     interstate transportation of stolen money, and money laundering in\r     connection with a scheme to defraud investors through the purported sale of\r     Guaranteed Insurance Contracts to be issued by major European insurance\r     companies ( GICs ).  A third participant in the scheme, Harry Walker, pled\r     guilty in March 1997 to one count of money laundering. The case is being\r     prosecuted by the United States Attorney s Office for the Eastern District\r     of Missouri.\r\r          According to the indictment, in 1993 and 1994, Howard, 50, and\r     Robinson, 31, told numerous persons that a company with which they were\r     affiliated, M.T.L. International Finance, Inc., had obtained the right to\r     sell the GICs in the United States.  A GIC is a contract by which an\r     insurance company obtains money by pledging its accounts receivable for\r     future premium receipts.  The defendants allegedly represented that GICs\r     could be purchased from the European insurance companies and resold at a\r     profit on a continuous basis.  The indictment charges that Howard and\r     Robinson obtained $550,000 from five individual investors, which instead of\r     investing they misappropriated for their own use.\r\r          The indictment, which was returned under seal on November 26, 1997,\r     was unsealed after Robinson was arrested in California on December 17,\r     1997, released on a $25,000 bond, and ordered to appear in St. Louis on\r     January 5, 1998.  Howard, a St. Louis resident, was arrested on December 2,\r     1997, and released on a $10,000 bond.  Howard s trial is currently\r     scheduled for February 2, 1998, in the U.S. District Court in St. Louis. \r     The defendants face up to five years  imprisonment for each count of\r     conspiracy and wire fraud, and up to ten years for each count of interstate\r     transportation of stolen money and money laundering.  Walker has not yet\r     been sentenced on his guilty plea.\r\r          Howard, Robinson, and Walker are also defendants in a civil securities\r     fraud action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission based on the\r     same scheme.  The Commission s action was filed in the U.S. District Court\r     in Manhattan in September 1996.  At the same time, the Commission s\r     Division of Enforcement brought public administrative proceedings against\r     Sidney H. Stires, a New York stockbroker, and his firm, Stires & Co., Inc.,\r\r\r\r\r                                        - 2 -\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     alleging that they engaged in securities fraud in connection with the GIC\r     scheme.  A hearing in that matter was held before an administrative law\r     judge in February 1997, but no decision has been issued.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15607 / January 6, 1998\r\r     Securities and Exchange Commission v. Susan L. Hirsch et al.\r     Civil No. CV 497-060 (WM) (S.D. Ga.) (filed March 20, 1997)\r\r     On December 29, 1997, Judge William Moore of the United Stated District\r     Court for the District of Georgia entered final judgments against Susan L.\r     Hirsch, Gregory M. Hirsch, Danny B. Kaminsky, Lewis A. Kooden, Daniel H.\r     Klugman and Michael D. Kooden in an insider trading case brought by the\r     Securities and Exchange Commission.  The judgments permanently enjoin the\r     defendants from future violations of Sections 10(b) and 14(e) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Rules 10b-5 and 14e-3 thereunder, and\r     require the defendants, collectively, to pay $604,704 in disgorgement of\r     illegal trading profits, civil penalties and prejudgment interest. \r     Defendants consented to the final judgments without admitting or denying\r     the allegations against them.  \r\r          The Commission alleged that the defendants engaged in insider trading\r     in advance of the July 1995 announcement that Sandoz, Ltd. was making a\r     cash tender offer for the securities of Genetic Therapy, Inc. (GTI). \r     Specifically, the Commission alleged that Susan Hirsch, a former senior\r     account representative of Ruder-Finn, Inc., a New York-based public\r     relations firm, obtained non-public information about Sandoz\s confidential\r     bid for GTI during the course of her employment at Ruder-Finn in advance of\r     the Sandoz/GTI tender offer announcement, and improperly passed that\r     information to her brother Gregory Hirsch, a certified public accountant in\r     Savannah, Georgia.  The complaint alleged that Gregory Hirsch tipped and\r     purchased GTI common stock and call options jointly with a friend in\r     Savannah, Danny Kaminsky, in advance of the announcement for profits of\r     $251,190.  The complaint further alleged that on Friday, July 7, 1995, the\r     last trading day before the tender offer announcement, Kaminsky purchased\r     45 GTI call option contracts through a brokerage account of one of his\r     friends, at a time when Kaminsky knew that Sandoz was going to announce its\r     tender offer for GTI at $21 per share on the following Monday.\r\r          The complaint also alleged that Gregory Hirsch and Danny Kaminsky\r     tipped Lewis Kooden, Daniel Klugman and Michael Kooden, who purchased GTI\r     common stock and call options for illegal profits of $43,795, $28,107 and\r     $14,666, respectively.  In addition, the complaint alleged that Michael\r     Kooden caused others to trade in GTI securities.\r\r          Under the terms of the final judgment, Susan Hirsch was not ordered to\r     pay any disgorgement, civil penalties or prejudgment interest based upon\r     her demonstrated inability to pay.  Greg Hirsch was ordered to pay $93,837,\r     which represented a portion of his alleged trading profits; based upon his\r     demonstrated inability to pay, disgorgement of the remainder of his trading\r     profits and prejudgment interest were waived, and he was not ordered to pay\r     civil penalties.  Danny Kaminsky was ordered to pay $125,645 in\r     disgorgement, which represented the trading profits he allegedly received\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     with Greg Hirsch, $169,440 in civil penalties and $25,244 in prejudgment\r     interest.   Lewis Kooden, Daniel Klugman and Michael Kooden were ordered to\r     pay $43,795, $28,107 and $14,666, respectively, which represents full\r     disgorgement of their trading profits, an equal amount in civil penalties,\r     plus $8,799, $5,647 and $2,947, respectively, in prejudgment interest.\r\r          For further information, see Litigation Release No. 15302 (March 20,\r     1997).\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15608 / January 6, 1998\r\r     ACCOUNTING AND AUDITING ENFORCEMENT\r     RELEASE NO. 1004 / January 6, 1998\r\r     SEC V. INTERNATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS & TECHNOLOGIES, CORP., F/K/A MOBILE\r     SERVICES INTERNATIONAL CORP., JAMES C. COBBAN, JAMES M. ROBINSON AND\r     JONATHAN D. BENNETT, Civil Action No. 96-8490-CIV-HURLEY/LYNCH\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) announced that\r     on December 18, 1997, Final Judgments of Permanent Injunctions were entered\r     against James C. Cobban (Cobban), James M. Robinson (Robinson) and\r     Jonathan D. Bennett (Bennett) (collectively, the defendants) by the\r     United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida.  The\r     Final Judgments enjoin Cobban and Robinson from future violations of\r     Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (Exchange Act) and\r     Rules 10b-5 and 13b2-2, promulgated thereunder, and enjoins Bennett from\r     future violations of Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5,\r     thereunder.  The Final Judgments did not order Cobban, Robinson and Bennett\r     to pay civil penalties based on their demonstrated financial inability to\r     pay.  Cobban, Robinson and Bennett are all former officers and directors of\r     International Communications & Technologies, Corp., f/k/a Mobile Services\r     International Corporation (Mobile Services), a mobile telecommunications\r     company formerly based in Boca Raton, Florida.  The defendants consented to\r     the entry of the Final Judgments without admitting or denying the\r     Commission\s allegations.\r\r          The Commission\s Complaint, filed on July 3, 1996, alleged that Mobile\r     Services made false filings with the Commission during fiscal years 1993\r     and 1994.  Specifically, the Complaint alleged that Mobile Services valued\r     certain franchise rights as exceeding $4 million, when, in truth, these\r     franchise rights were worthless; the allegedly overvalued assets\r     represented over 80 percent of Mobile Services\ assets.  The Complaint\r     alleged that the defendants knew that the franchisor was defunct, with the\r     result that the franchise rights were materially impaired when the filings\r     were made.  The Complaint also alleged that Cobban and Robinson made false\r     and misleading statements and omissions to Mobile Services\ independent\r     auditor in connection with his audit of the company\s 1993 financial\r     statements.  The Complaint further alleged that Mobile Services failed to\r     make and keep books and records which accurately and fairly reflected its\r     financial and accounting transactions.\r\r

b                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15609 / January 6, 1998     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. STEVEN SAMBLIS, ET AL. Case No. 98-     001-CIV-ORL-22-C.          The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) announced that it filed     a complaint today in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of     Florida in Orlando against Steven Samblis and his corporation New Stock,     Inc. (NSI).  According to the SEC\s Complaint, Defendant Samblis is a     resident of the Orlando, Florida area and self-professed stock picker.  The     SEC alleges that Samblis, together with co-defendant NSI, is passing     himself off as an independent and impartial stock picker when, in fact, he     is nothing more than a paid pitch man for the companies he hypes.          In its Complaint, the SEC alleges that in October 1997 Samblis     published a magazine, New Stock, in which he enthusiastically recommended     the securities of certain publicly-traded companies without disclosing that     he had been paid at least $20,000 to make these recommendations.  The SEC     also alleges that Samblis was paid to issue thousands of E-mails over the     Internet regarding these same securities.  The SEC learned of Samblis\     activities when detected by the Enforcement Division\s Internet     Surveillance program.          The SEC is seeking an expedited hearing and preliminary injunction     against Samblis and NSI for violating Section 17(b) of the Securities Act     of 1933.  Section 17(b) makes it illegal for any person to distribute any     publication recommending a security while being paid to do so without fully     disclosing that he has been or will be paid for recommending the stock and     the amount he has been or will be paid.  In addition to a preliminary     injunction, the SEC seeks a permanent injunction against Samblis and NSI,     disgorgement of ill-gotten profits, and civil money penalties.          Investors are advised to read the SEC\s Cyberspace Alert before     purchasing any investment promoted on the  Internet.  The free publication,     which alerts investors to the telltale signs of online investment fraud, is     available on the Investor Assistance and Complaints link of the SEC\s Home     page on the World Wide Web <www.sec.gov>. It can also be obtained by     calling 800-SEC-0330.  Investors are encouraged to report suspicious     Internet  offerings (or other suspicious offerings) via e-mail to      <enforcement@sec.gov>. A user-friendly form to assist you in making a report      is available at the  Enforcement Complaint Center on the Enforcement Division     link of the SEC Home Page <www.sec.gov>. Investors can also mail a report     to the SEC\s Enforcement Complaint Center,  Mail Stop 8-4, 450 Fifth     Street, Washington, D.C. 20549.                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15610 / January 6, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. KINLAW SECURITIES CORP., et al.,\r     3:93-CV-2010-T, USDC, ND/TX (Dallas Division)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) announced that\r     Final Judgments of Permanent Injunction and Other Equitable Relief were\r     entered in United States District Court in Dallas, Texas, against Dyke\r     Ferrell and Bret L. Boteler on December 18, 1997, and against James B.\r     Boswell and Cecil E. Glass III on December 23, 1997, enjoining them from\r     future violations of the federal securities laws. The defendants consented\r     to the entry of the final judgments without admitting or denying the\r     allegations contained in the Commission\s First Amended Complaint. All the\r     defendants are former sales representatives of the now defunct Kinlaw\r     Securities Corporation, a broker dealer formerly registered with the\r     Commission which offered and sold securities in the form of investment\r     contracts involving interests in oil and gas drilling ventures. \r\r          The Commission\s First Amended Complaint alleged that in the offer and\r     sale of the oil and gas drilling ventures, the defendants made material\r     misrepresentations and omissions of material fact concerning, among other\r     things, the risks and expected returns associated with the oil and gas\r     investments, the costs to drill and complete oil and gas wells, and the\r     success of prior oil and gas wells, all in violation of Sections 5(a), 5(c)\r     and 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, and Section 10(b) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. \r\r          The court also ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement in the\r     following amounts: 1) Ferrell - $412,500, plus prejudgment interest of\r     $244,077; 2) Boteler -  $297,536 plus prejudgment interest of $185,061; 3)\r     Boswell - $1,243,000 plus prejudgment interest of $56,564; and 4) Glass - \r     $1,142,658 plus prejudgment interest of $51,998. \r\r          Based on their demonstrated financial inability to pay, the full\r     disgorgement amounts for Boteler and Glass were waived. Payment of all but\r     $26,000 of Ferrell\s disgorgement amount was waived based on his\r     demonstrated financial inability to pay the full amount, and payment of all\r     but $1,628 of Boswell\s disgorgement was waived based on his demonstrated\r     financial inability to pay the full amount. Additionally, the court did not\r     impose civil penalties against the defendants because of their poor\r     financial condition.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No.  15611 / January 7, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. JAMES FRITH and CHICAGO PARTNERSHIP\r     BOARD, INC., DEFENDANTS and ADBOT, INC, RELIEF DEFENDANT (United States\r     District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, No. 97 C 8440).\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that it obtained a\r     Final Judgment and Order of Permanent Injunction against James Frith\r     (Frith) and Chicago Partnership Board, Inc. (CPB).  The Order, entered on\r     December 15, 1997, enjoins Frith and the CPB from continuing to engage in\r     violations of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act, Sections 10(b),\r     15(c)(1), 15(c)(3), 17(a) and 17(e) of the Exchange Act and Rules 10b-5,\r     15c1-2, 15c3-1, 15c3-3, 17a-3 and 17a-5 thereunder.\r\r          The Commission s complaint alleged that from approximately May 1996\r     through December 1997, Frith fraudulently diverted at least $3.4 million in\r     funds owed to CPBs brokerage customers in connection with transactions in\r     limited partnership units, and used those funds for a variety of personal\r     and business expenses.  The complaint alleged that in order to disguise the\r     effect of the misappropriation, Frith personally assumed approximately $3.4\r     million in liabilities to sellers, and improperly removed those liabilities\r     from CPBs books.  In doing so, CPB failed to maintain sufficient funds in\r     a special reserve account required for the protection of customers and\r     failed to maintain the legally required amount of net capital for an\r     extended period.  In addition, the complaint alleged that CPB and Frith\r     submitted false reports based on CPBs inaccurate books and records to the\r     Commission on an annual basis, and the National Association of Securities\r     Dealers on a monthly and quarterly basis.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15612 / January 8, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. THE TRUST GROUP, LTD.,\r     ET AL., Civil Action No. 95-5 (E.D.Ky.)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) announced that\r     the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky\r     entered Final Judgments of Permanent Injunction against defendants The\r     Trust Group, Ltd. (TTG), Jeffrey M. Mortiz, Sandra L. Kalez, Laurent M.\r     Gerschel, and T. Robert Hughes on December 30, 1997.  The Court also\r     ordered the defendants to pay, jointly and severally, a $50,000 civil\r     penalty. As previously announced, the Commission alleged in its Complaint\r     that the defendants had defrauded investors by offering investments of tens\r     of millions of dollars in a so-called roll program administered by\r     defendant TTG, through which the defendants purported to trade bank\r     debentures, notes, guarantees, and stand-by letters of credit, purportedly\r     issued by the leading world prime banks.  The Commission further alleged\r     that the defendants had represented to prospective investors that their\r     roll program would yield an annual return on investment of at least 48%\r     with a level of risk that was consistent with proven, prudent trust\r     portfolio management, and/or pension fund guidelines.  The Commission\r     alleged that, in fact, the defendants had no roll program or other\r     investment program.\r\r          The defendants consented to the entry of the permanent injunctions and\r     civil penalty without admitting or denying the allegations in the\r     Complaint. The injunctions prohibit the defendants from violating Section\r     17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities\r     Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, which are the principal\r     antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws. (For further\r     information, see Litigation Release No. 14382, January 17, 1995.)\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15613 / January 8, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. RAUSCHER PIERCE REFSNES, INC. and\r     JAMES R. FELTHAM, Case No. CV-98-0027 PHX ROS\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed a civil fraud\r     action against Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, Inc. and its former Senior Vice\r     President, James R. Feltham, in the United States District Court for the\r     District of Arizona.  The Commission\s complaint alleges that Rauscher and\r     Feltham defrauded their financial advisory client, the State of Arizona\r     Department of Administration (DOA  or the State), in connection with\r     DOA\s issuance of $129,640,000 of Series 1992B Refunding Certificates of\r     Participation (the 1992B COPs).  As part of the 1992B COPs offering, the\r     defendants allegedly sold certain United States Treasury securities (the\r     escrow securities) to the State at above-market prices.  According to the\r     complaint, inflating the escrow securities\ prices reduced the yields on\r     those securities and enabled Rauscher to make illegal profits at the\r     expense of the federal government while purporting to comply with the\r     federal tax laws governing the 1992B COPs offering, a practice commonly\r     referred to as yield burning.  Rauscher allegedly took an undisclosed\r     $707,037 profit on its sales to DOA.  The complaint further alleges that\r     Rauscher and Feltham failed to inform their client of this profit or that\r     any of the sales prices of the escrow securities had been inflated. \r     Instead, Rauscher and Feltham issued a materially false tax certification\r     (the Certification) in connection with the sale of the escrow securities \r     which falsely stated that Rauscher\s sale prices for the escrow securities\r     equalled their fair market value, that Rauscher\s sale of the securities\r     was an arm\s length transaction, and that Rauscher had priced the escrow\r     securities without regard to the yield of those securities.\r\r          The Commission\s complaint further charges that the State\s ability to\r     successfully market the 1992B COPs depended on the securities\ tax-exempt\r     status under federal law, and that the defendants\ alleged overcharges in\r     violation of applicable tax laws and regulations jeopardized the tax-exempt\r     status of the 1992B COPs.\r\r          According to the complaint, Rauscher and Feltham charged DOA a\r     fraudulent and excessive undisclosed markup on the escrow securities, in\r     that the prices charged DOA for such securities were not reasonably related\r     to prevailing market prices, and Rauscher\s $707,037 profit from the sale\r     of such securities was unreasonable in light of the circumstances\r     surrounding the sale.\r\r          Finally, the complaint alleges that in their capacities as financial\r     adviser and investment adviser to DOA, Rauscher and Feltham owed DOA\r     fiduciary duties to provide DOA with complete information and unbiased\r     advice and assistance in all aspects of the 1992B COPs offering.  The\r     defendants allegedly violated these duties by failing to disclose the\r     conflict of interest inherent in their selling DOA the escrow securities as\r     principal from Rauscher\s own account and taking the secret $707,037 profit\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     while at the same time purporting to give DOA independent investment\r     advice.\r\r          The complaint requests the Court to enjoin Rauscher from violating the\r     antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933,\r     Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5\r     thereunder, and Sections 206(1), (2), (3) of the Investment Advisers Act of\r     1940; to enjoin Feltham from violating Section 17(a) of the Securities Act\r     of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule\r     10b-5 thereunder; and to enjoin Feltham from aiding and abetting violations\r     of Sections 206(1), (2), and (3) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. \r     The complaint further requests the Court to order Rauscher and Feltham to\r     disgorge the profits from their illegal conduct and to impose civil\r     monetary penalties against them.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     \r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15614 / January 9, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. AFFORDABLE PREPAID CELLULAR, INC. AND\r     JOHN C. ROCKETT, Civil Action No. 97-3750 RAP (JGx) (C.D. Cal.).\r\r     The Commission announced that on January 5, 1998, the Honorable Richard A.\r     Paez, United States District Judge, entered an order that the monies frozen\r     in this action be disbursed to investors, and appointing a disbursing\r     agent. Additionally, on December 23, 1997, Judge Paez entered default\r     judgments against the defendants in this action, Affordable Prepaid\r     Cellular, Inc., and its owner, John C. Rockett (Rockett). The default\r     judgments also ordered disgorgement in the amount of $1,338,709.79 together\r     with prejudgment interest of $37,524.95, jointly and severally, against APC\r     and Rockett.\r\r     Approximately $280,600 of the $1,355,000 raised from investors was frozen\r     pursuant to an Order Freezing Assets obtained by the Commission on May 23,\r     1997.  The frozen funds were awarded to the Commission as disgorgement, and\r     will be disbursed to investors proportionately, resulting in a return to\r     investors of approximately 20 cents per dollar invested.  The disbursement\r     will take place on or before March 5, 1998.\r\r     The Commission charged in its Complaint, initially filed as a temporary\r     restraining order on May 20, 1997, that APC, located in Lake Forest,\r     California, and its owner Rockett fraudulently offered and/or sold units in\r     APC, in the form of $5,000 corporate notes, to at least one hundred\r     individuals since December 1996.  APC\s\r     stated business was to provide prepaid cellular telephone service to\r     credit-challenged individuals.  According to APC, in return for their\r     investment, APC promised investors a guaranteed 16 3/4% annual return, plus\r     1% of half of APC\s profits, and that the investor\s original contribution\r     would be returned at the end of one year.  Further, APC promised that\r     investors\ monies would be used to fund APC\s business operations. \r     Instead, however, Rockett misused and misappropriated at least $600,000 of\r     the approximately $1,355,000 raised from investors.  Of the monies the\r     Commission was able to trace, the Commission found that Rockett paid\r     himself cash payments of over $420,000, and made substantial payments to\r     APC s sales agents.  Additionally, no significant monies were spent to fund\r     APC s business.  Rockett also failed to inform investors that he had a long\r     history of securities law violations, including being twice convicted for\r     selling fraudulent investments and being the subject of numerous state\r     orders for violating state securities laws. \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15615 / January 13, 1998                   \r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. SUNBELT DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION,\r     WENDELL ROGERS, DONALD HAMMOND, AND WILLIS DAVIS (Civil Action No. 1: 97-\r     CV-1387, W.D. La.)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that, on January 5,\r     1998, the Honorable F.A. Little, United States District Judge for the\r     Western District of Louisiana, Alexandria Division, entered default\r     judgments against defendants, Sunbelt Development Corporation ( Sunbelt),\r     a Louisiana corporation; Wendell Rogers (Rogers), director and co-founder\r     of Sunbelt; and Donald Hammond (Hammond)for failing to respond to a\r     complaint filed by the Commission seeking permanent injunctions,\r     disgorgement and civil penalties.  Orders of permanent injunction were\r     entered against Sunbelt, Rogers and Hammond enjoining them from further\r     violations of Sections 5 and 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and\r     Sections 15(a) and 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule\r     10b-5 thereunder.\r\r          The Court ordered disgorgement of all ill-gotten gains received by the\r     defendants from their scheme. Sunbelt was ordered to pay disgorgement in\r     the amount of $2,560,842 plus prejudgment interest; Rogers was ordered to\r     pay $1,502,842 in disgorgement along with prejudgment interest thereon; and\r     Hammond was ordered to pay disgorgement in the amount of $947,347 along\r     with prejudgment interest thereon.  Disgorgement is to be paid by each\r     defendant within 30 days of the date of the Court s order.  Further,\r     Sunbelt, Rogers and Hammond were each ordered to pay a civil penalty, which\r     will be determined at a later date, upon motion by the Commission.\r\r          The Commission\s complaint alleged that violations of the antifraud\r     provisions of the securities laws by the defendants occurred between mid-\r     1993 and mid-1994.  Rogers and Hammond, who are both ministers,\r     misrepresented or omitted material facts when they sold securities to\r     members of their respective churches, to members of churches of the same\r     denomination, and to friends and relatives of the church members.  The\r     defendants promised exorbitant returns on investments along with the return\r     of the investors\ principal when, in fact, Sunbelt was actually operating a\r     Ponzi scheme.  More than $3.5 million worth of unregistered securities were\r     issued to over 200 individuals in at least 16 states during the scheme.\r      \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15616 / January 16, 1998\r\r     SEC v. STRUTHERS INDUSTRIES, INC. and WINCO CORP., Misc. No. 97-305 (D.D.C.\r     January 12, 1998)\r\r          On January 12, 1998, Judge Thomas F. Hogan of the United States\r     District for the District of Columbia found Struthers Industries, Inc. and\r     WINCO Corp. in civil contempt of court for failing to obey the court s\r     prior order enforcing the Securities and Exchange Commission s document\r     subpoenas to the two companies. Struthers and WINCO are affiliated Los\r     Angeles companies involved in seeking commercial applications for\r     Interactive Video and Data Services and other Federal Communications\r     Commission broadcast licenses. Judge Hogan ordered Struthers and WINCO to\r     produce all documents responsive to the subpoenas by 10:30 a.m. on January\r     13, 1998 (January 15 for any documents located in California), and to make\r     their custodians of records available for testimony at the Commission s\r     Washington, D.C. office by January 26, 1998. The court also ordered that\r     both companies separately pay a fine of $1,000 per day for each day they\r     fail to purge their contempt by complying with the court s order. Struthers\r     produced documents to the Commission on January 12 shortly after the\r     court s order was issued.\r\r          Struthers  common stock is traded on the Over-the-Counter Bulletin\r     Board. On January 9, 1998, the Commission suspended trading in Struthers \r     securities based on questions regarding the accuracy of certain statements\r     and regarding material omissions in the company s public disclosures. In\r     particular, the Commission s order noted questions concerning (1) the value\r     of certain broadcast licenses in which Struthers claims to have an\r     ownership interest, (2) the presence of or potential for a recapitalization\r     which will enable Struthers to pursue its business plan, and (3) the\r     resignation of Struthers  auditors.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r                     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                              Washington, D.C.\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15617 / January 14, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. SHELDON KRAFT, Civil Action No. 98-\r     CV-00095 (GK)(D.D.C.)\r\r     UNITED STATES v. SHELDON KRAFT, Cr. 98-18-A (E.D. VA.)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) today filed a\r     Complaint against Sheldon Kraft ( Kraft ), 46, a New York City stock\r     broker, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. \r     This case is another in a line of significant Commission enforcement\r     actions and/or criminal prosecutions arising from this wide-ranging\r     investigation of microcap fraud involving Systems of Excellence, Inc.\r     ( SOE ) and other issuers.  The Complaint alleges that Kraft acted as the\r     principal facilitator for Charles O. Huttoe ( Huttoe ), formerly the\r     Chairman and CEO of SOE, in manipulating the market for the securities of\r     that company.  Simultaneously with the filing of the Complaint, Kraft\r     consented, without admitting or denying the Commission s allegations, to an\r     order enjoining him from violations of the securities registration and\r     antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws, and requiring him to\r     disgorge his illegal gains of $3,193,337 from the manipulation of SOE\r     securities, together with prejudgment interest.  In satisfaction of the\r     disgorgement judgment, Kraft will disgorge all of his assets except his\r     residence and household items.  The disgorged assets include $1,107,000 in\r     cash, plus certain real estate and claims that he has against his former\r     employer. Any remainder of the disgorgement amount will be waived in light\r     of Kraft s demonstrated inability to pay based on his sworn representations\r     in his statement of financial condition.  Kraft also agreed to a Commission\r     order barring him from the securities industry and from participating in an\r     offering of penny stock.  The Commission s Complaint alleges the following: \r\r\r          Kraft met Huttoe in early 1995, and thereafter guided Huttoe\r     throughout the manipulation of SOE. When SOE s original software business\r     collapsed, Kraft found a high-tech video teleconferencing business to put\r     into the SOE shell so as to make it attractive to investors.  Thereafter,\r     Kraft introduced Huttoe to his  total world  -- Kraft s network of brokers,\r     market makers, and stock touters -- who Huttoe then bribed with SOE stock\r     to manipulate the price of SOE.  As a result of Kraft s introductions,\r     Huttoe entered into such arrangements with five stock promoters who were to\r     push sales of SOE stock to retail brokerage customers, three stock touters\r     who would disseminate recommendations to purchase SOE via mass media and\r     other means, and two traders at market making broker-dealer firms who\r     agreed to support the price of SOE.  As a result of these and other\r     manipulative activities, SOE s stock price rose from pennies to $4 9/16 per\r     share in just a few months.  In addition, Kraft directed Huttoe in\r     establishing nominee accounts through which Kraft secretly sold more than\r     6.3 million shares of SOE stock for Huttoe into the inflated market, on\r     which Huttoe realized proceeds of approximately $9.62 million of his more\r     than $12.5 million of illegal profits derived from the SOE manipulation. \r\r          For his part in the SOE fraud, Kraft demanded compensation in the form\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r     of direct cash payments from Huttoe and free trading shares of SOE stock\r     that he had Huttoe issue in the names of his nominees. Kraft also obtained\r     kickbacks from the persons he introduced to Huttoe in the form of cash or a\r     portion of the SOE stock Huttoe supplied them in exchange for carrying out\r     their roles in the manipulation.  Kraft then sold his free SOE stock  --  a\r     total of approximately 1.66 million shares -- into the inflated market\r     through nominee accounts in the United States and Canada.  In addition, in\r     exchange for directing the illegal sales of SOE stock in Huttoe s nominee\r     accounts, Kraft received his ordinary commissions, and a percentage of the\r     proceeds from the sale of stock through Huttoe s nominee accounts.  In\r     total, Kraft made illegal profits of $3,193,337 from his role in the SOE\r     scheme. \r      \r          The Commission\s Complaint alleges that as a result of that conduct\r     Kraft violated Sections 5 and 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, and\r     Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5\r     thereunder.  The court order to which Kraft consented enjoins him from\r     future violations of those provisions.  Kraft also consented to the entry\r     of a Commission order pursuant to Sections 15(b) and 19(h) of the Exchange\r     Act barring him from association with any broker, dealer, municipal\r     securities dealer, investment adviser or investment company, or\r     participation in any offering of penny stock, based on the entry of the\r     above injunction.\r\r          Also today in the United States District Court for the Eastern\r     District of Virginia, Kraft pleaded guilty to a two-count criminal\r     information charging him with one count of conspiracy to commit securities\r     fraud and money laundering and one count of failure to file tax returns. \r     Kraft\s plea was in connection with, among other things, the fraud\r     involving SOE.\r\r     Background\r\r          The Commission Prosecutions\r\r          The cases against Kraft are the latest in a series of actions that the\r     Commission and criminal authorities have filed against a number of\r     individuals and entities related to the manipulation of the securities of\r     SOE and two other microcap companies.  On November 7, 1996, the Commission\r     filed a Complaint and obtained emergency relief against Huttoe and twelve\r     other defendants, including SGA Goldstar Research, Inc., which disseminated\r     a tout sheet over the internet, and its principals, Theodore R. Melcher,\r     Jr. and Shannon B. Terry.  See SEC v. Huttoe, Et Al., 96-CV-02543\r     (GK)(D.D.C.).  Kraft was responsible for introducing Huttoe to SGA\r     Goldstar.  The Complaint alleged a massive ongoing market manipulation\r     orchestrated by Huttoe in which he executed an unregistered distribution of\r     tens of millions of SOE shares.  The Complaint further alleged that Huttoe\r     artificially inflated the price for those shares by issuing materially\r     false press releases about nonexistent multimillion dollar sales of SOE\r     products, filing false periodic reports with the Commission, and bribing\r     with SOE stock persons to tout SOE stock, including Melcher and Terry.  As\r     a final part of the scheme, Huttoe, Melcher, and Terry then took advantage\r     of the inflated market by dumping shares on unwitting investors.  On\r     January 29, 1997, the Commission amended the Complaint to allege that in\r     addition to touting SOE stock, SGA Goldstar, Melcher, and Terry engaged in\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r     a systematic practice of publishing promotional coverage for other issuers\r     in exchange for compensation.  On November 25, 1997, Huttoe settled the\r     Commission s action by consenting to an order permanently enjoining him\r     from violations of certain provisions of the federal securities laws,\r     barring him from acting as an officer or director of a public company, and\r     requiring him to disgorge over $12.5 million, the amount he derived from\r     the SOE manipulation, provided that except for surrendering certain assets,\r     payment of the full disgorgement amount was waived in light of his\r     demonstrated inability to pay.  Huttoe also consented to a Commission order\r     barring him from the securities industry.  The actions against SGA\r     Goldstar, Melcher, and Terry are pending.\r\r          In a separate action filed on December 22, 1997, the Commission sued\r     Barclay Davis, a Las Vegas, Nevada based penny stock promoter that Kraft\r     introduced to Huttoe.  See SEC v. Davis, Et Al., 97-CV-03056 (GK)(D.D.C.). \r     The Complaint against Davis alleges that Davis entered the ongoing scheme\r     to manipulate the market for SOE, and that Huttoe gave Davis unregistered\r     shares of SOE stock to facilitate the use of a registered broker-dealer to\r     push SOE stock on the public.  The Complaint against Davis further alleges\r     that he engineered the falsification by SOE of Commission filings, and that\r     he arranged for his  team,  which included CPA Merle S. Finkel, to\r     accomplish this. The Complaint against Davis also alleges that he used two\r     other microcap companies that he controlled, Bio-Tech Industries, Inc.\r     ( Bio-Tech ) (formerly Twenty First Century Health, Inc.) and Combined\r     Companies International Corp. ( CCIC ), as vehicles for market\r     manipulations.  The action against Davis is pending.  In another action,\r     the Commission sued CPA Finkel, the former auditor of SOE, Bio-Tech, and\r     CCIC alleging that on at least 13 occasions, Finkel issued materially false\r     or inaccurate audit reports on the financial statements of these companies. \r     See SEC v. Finkel, 97-CV-00505 (EGS)(D.D.C.).  Finkel settled that action\r     by consenting to a permanent injunction against future violations of\r     certain provisions of the federal securities laws, and also consented to a\r     Commission order denying him the privilege of appearing or practicing\r     before the Commission as an accountant.\r\r          The Criminal Prosecutions\r\r          In terms of criminal actions, Kraft is the fifth individual to plead\r     guilty to felony charges stemming from these matters.  On January 31, 1997,\r     Huttoe, who presently is incarcerated, was sentenced to a federal prison\r     term of 46 months, followed by two years supervised release, and a $10,000\r     fine, pursuant to a criminal information charging him with one count of\r     securities fraud and one count of money laundering.  On March 12, 1997,\r     Finkel pleaded guilty to a criminal information charging him with one count\r     of conspiracy to commit securities fraud and bank fraud, and is awaiting\r     sentencing.  On September 12, 1997, Melcher, who presently is incarcerated,\r     was sentenced to a prison term of 12 months, followed by two years\r     supervised release, and a $20,000 fine, pursuant to a criminal information\r     charging him with conspiracy to commit securities fraud.  On December 22,\r     1997, Davis, who is awaiting sentencing, pleaded guilty to one count of\r     conspiracy to commit securities fraud and bank fraud, and one count of\r     money laundering.\r     *   *   *\r\r          The Commission previously has issued a number of releases concerning\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 3======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r     these and other related matters.  See Lit. Rel. 15600 (December 22, 1997);\r     Lit. Rel. 15571 (November 25, 1997); Lit. Rel. 15490 (September 12, 1997);\r     Securities Exchange Act Rel. No. 38691 (May 29, 1997); Securities Exchange\r     Act Rel. No. 38653 (May 19, 1997); Lit. Rel. 15286 (March 12, 1997);\r     Securities Exchange Act Rel. No. 38345 (February 27, 1997); Securities\r     Exchange Act Rel. No. 38260 (February 10, 1997); Lit. Rel. 15490 (January\r     31, 1997); Lit. Rel. 15185 (December 12, 1996); Lit. Rel. 15153 (November\r     7, 1996); Securities Exchange Act Rel. No. 33791 (October 7, 1996).\r\r          The Commission is cooperating with separate investigations in this\r     matter carried on by the United States Attorney\s Offices for the District\r     of Nevada and the Eastern District of Virginia, and the Criminal\r     Investigation Division of the Internal Revenue Service.  \r\r          The Commission\s investigation in this matter is continuing.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 4======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r          Securities and Exchange Commission\r     Washington, D.C.\r\r     Litigation Release 15618 / January 14, 1998                 \r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. J. SCOTT ESKIND\r     (Civil Action No. 1: 97-CV-1790-CAM, N.D. Ga.)\r\r     The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that on January 12, 1998,\r     the Honorable Charles A. Moye, Jr., United States District Judge for the\r     Northern District of Georgia, entered an order of permanent injunction and\r     other relief as to defendant J. Scott Eskind (Eskind), of Atlanta,\r     Georgia.  The order permanently enjoins and restrains Eskind from violating\r     Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, Section 10(b) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and Section 206\r     of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.  Eskind was ordered to pay\r     disgorgement in the amount of $542,532, representing the ill-gotten gains\r     received by Eskind, and prejudgment interest thereon. Civil penalties will\r     be set by the Court at a later date, upon motion by the Commission. \r\r     Eskind consented to the relief without admitting or denying the allegations\r     set forth in a complaint, filed by the Commission on June 20, 1997.  In its\r     complaint, the Commission alleged that, between November 1994 and May 1996,\r     Eskind was secretary and treasurer of Tower Asset Management (Tower), the\r     general partner and investment adviser of Asset Management Fund, L.P.\r     (Asset Management), a limited partnership formed for the purpose of\r     investing in securities.  In or before April 1996, Eskind misappropriated\r     or converted approximately $246,000 of Asset Management\s assets, and\r     concealed his actions by falsifying the partnership\s books.  When the\r     thefts were discovered, Eskind was terminated by Tower.  \r\r     After his dismissal from Tower, Eskind solicited investments from the\r     public using Asset Management\s offering documents.  Between December 1996\r     and May 1997, Eskind induced or attempted to induce at least three\r     investors to invest in what was falsely purported to be Asset Management. \r     Eskind persuaded two of the investors to invest, respectively, $500,000 and\r     $150,000 in his scheme.  Eskind did not disclose to the investors that he\r     had been terminated by Tower nor did he disclose that Asset Management had\r     been dissolved.\r\r\r            \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15619 / January 15, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. ROBERT C. WILSON, ET AL., Civil\r     Action No. 95-WM-3174 (D.Colorado)\r\r     UNITED STATES V. ROBERT C. WILSON, Nos. 97-189-CR-T-99 (E) (M.D. Florida)\r     and CR97-178 (C.D. Ca.)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that on January 12,\r     1998 Stephen V. Wilson, United States District Judge (C.D.Ca.), sentenced\r     Robert C. Wilson (Wilson) to a federal prison term of 57 months on his\r     guilty plea to charges in Florida and 46 months on his plea to charges in\r     California.  \r\r          The criminal information filed in the U. S. District Court for the\r     Middle District of Florida  in May 1997 charged that Wilson defrauded the\r     United States Employer Consumer Self-Insurance Fund of Florida (USEC).\r     Wilson told USEC that the insurance company could increase its return on\r     investments by purchasing U.S. Treasury securities, with some additional\r     capital being contributed by Debenture Guaranty Corp.(Debenture), an\r     entity controlled by Wilson and Gary C. Long.  USEC liquidated $3.4 million\r     in investment assets and transferred the money to Debenture.  Wilson then\r     had a stockbroker confirm to USEC that $7.011 million in treasury\r     securities were held in its account.   The insurance company was not told,\r     however, that the securities were purchased on margin and that the\r     company\s account actually had a value of less than $600,000.  Next, Wilson \r     falsely represented to the company that Debenture had erroneously\r     contributed $2.3 million in excess funds to the company\s account for the\r     purchase of the treasury securities, and obtained USEC\s authorization to\r     wire transfer this money into Debenture\s account.  Unbeknownst to USEC,\r     the $2.3 million actually was the balance of USEC\s own money remaining\r     after the securities had been bought on margin.  Wilson later converted\r     these funds obtained from the insurance company to his own use.\r\r             Wilson was charged in the criminal information filed in the U. S.\r     District Court for the Central District of California in February 1997 with\r     running an advance fee swindle. Wilson told victims in that scheme that\r     their loan fee payments were secured by government securities.  In fact,\r     Wilson did not obtain loans for his victims, but instead used their fees\r     for his personal expenses.\r\r          Wilson and others were named as defendants in a parallel civil\r     injunctive action brought by the Commission on December 20, 1995. The\r     Commission\s complaint alleges that a number of investors were defrauded by\r     Wilson, Gary F. Long, Samuel L. Boyd, and Debenture Guaranty Corp. in a\r     scheme in which investors were solicited to invest in U.S. Treasury\r     securities, which purportedly would be traded using a proprietary method\r     that would produce unusually high yields.  According to the complaint,\r     investors\ funds were not, in fact, being invested in any high yield\r     investment program but were being misappropriated after a small portion of\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     the funds was used to purchase securities on margin.  The Commission\s\r     complaint further alleges that these misappropriated investor funds were\r     paid for the benefit of various participants in the scheme including\r     Wilson, Long, and Boyd.  The Commission obtained a temporary restraining\r     order, a preliminary injunction and an asset freeze against Wilson, Long,\r     Debenture Guaranty, Euro Scotia Funding (USA, Inc.) and Euro Scotia Group,\r     Ltd. in January  1996. Following a three day hearing, the Commission\s\r     request for a preliminary injunction and asset freeze as to defendant Boyd\r     and nominal defendants John J. Kenny, Kenny Capital Management, Inc.,\r     Nicholson/Kenny Capital Management, Inc., and Kenny Securities Corporation\r     was denied. The Commission\s litigation against all of the defendants and\r     nominal defendants in the civil case is ongoing.  See  Lit. Rel. 14761\r     (December 20, 1995)\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15620 / January 15, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. ENVIROMINT HOLDINGS, INC., et al.,\r     3:95-CV-2192-H, USDC, ND/TX (Dallas Division)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) announced that\r     on January 14, 1998, an Agreed Final Judgment was entered in United States\r     District Court in Dallas, Texas, against Robert Bogutski. Without admitting\r     or denying the allegations in the Commission\s complaint, Bogutski\r     consented to the entry of a permanent injunction enjoining him from future\r     violations of the anti-fraud provisions found in Section 10(b) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and transfer\r     agent recordkeeping provisions found in Section 17A(d)(1) and Rule 17Ad-10\r     thereunder.\r\r          The complaint alleged that Bogutski, who was president of Idata, Inc.,\r     a registered transfer agent, participated in a scheme relating to the offer\r     and sale of Enviromint Holdings, Inc. (EHI) securities. The Complaint\r     alleged that Bogutski destroyed Idata\s securities transfer records for\r     EHI\s predecessor company, and created false or misleading transfer records\r     for EHI.  By these activities, the principals of EHI converted shares of\r     the predecessor to themselves and their nominees, and concealed their\r     control of the company.\r        \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15621 / January 20, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. Uniglobe Trading Company, Inc., et.\r     al., 97 Civ. 08659 (USDC SDNY)\r\r          The Commission today announced that the U.S. District Court for the\r     Southern District of New York, White Plains Division, issued a preliminary\r     injunction and entered defaults in a pending action involving the offer to\r     sell forged and fictitious treasury bonds purportedly issued by the\r     government of Japan.  Judge Charles Brieant issued the preliminary\r     injunction today against five defendants named in the action on December\r     12, 1997 in the Commission s first amended complaint: Northeast Investment\r     Institution, Inc. (Northeast), a Fayetteville, North Carolina entity, and\r     four representatives of Northeast including Thomas Patrick McGlon\r     (president and a director), Daniel Watlington (secretary-treasurer and a\r     director), William Muwwakkil (vice-president and a director) and Tyrone P.\r     Jones, III (a special consultant).  The Court also entered default as to\r     Northeast, Watlington, Muwwakkil and Jones as a result of their failure to\r     plead or defend. Watlington, Muwwakkil and Jones live in Fayetteville,\r     North Carolina, and McGlon resides in Calhoun, Georgia.  \r\r          The Commission alleges that, since at least October of 1997, the\r     Northeast defendants have been engaging in an apparent scheme to defraud\r     U.S. investors through the offer of fraudulent Japanese treasury bonds. \r     The Commission asserts that Northeast and its representatives have offered\r     for sale as many as 24 treasury bonds purportedly issued by the Japanese\r     government totaling 12 billion yen (approximately [U.S.] $120 million). \r     The fraudulent bonds were seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in\r     October 1997, but the Northeast defendants allegedly continued to offer the\r     bonds on the theory that 12 replacement bonds were issued representing the\r     same supposed 12 billion yen debt obligation of Japan.  The Commission\r     introduced evidence from the Japanese government, the U.S. Secret Service,\r     two securities firms and a bank in support of its contention that the\r     purported bonds and other documents relating to a chain of custody for the\r     bonds are fraudulent.  The Commission s complaint charges the Northeast\r     defendants with violating the antifraud provisions, Section 17(a) of the\r     Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities and Exchange Act\r     of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.   \r\r          To prevent Northeast, McGlon, Watlington, Muwwakkil, and Jones from\r     continuing to offer and potentially sell these and other fictitious\r     securities, the Commission requested, and the Court granted, a preliminary\r     injunction, an order freezing the bonds, and an order that the Northeast\r     defendants tender the instruments to the registry of the Court.  Further,\r     the Judge\s order requires an accounting from the Northeast defendants of\r     all assets, including financial instruments or government bonds, held by\r     the Northeast defendants or offered by them for sale or other transfer from\r     September 1, 1997 to the date of the accounting.  The Commission also seeks\r     civil penalties against the Northeast defendants. \r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r          The Commission previously obtained similar injunctive relief in this\r     action against the five original defendants.  The Commission alleges in its\r     complaint that three of those defendants offered the fictitious Japanese\r     treasury bonds, and that all of the original defendants offered for sale at\r     least two, and possibly as many as sixteen, fraudulent certificates of\r     deposit of Banco de la Nacion Argentina with stated principal amounts of\r     [U.S.] $100 million each.  Judge Charles Brieant in December of 1997 issued\r     preliminary injunctions against Uniglobe Trading Company Inc., a Yonkers,\r     New York entity; two of its officers, Clint Holland and Margaret Laughrin;\r     Moorgreen Holdings Limited (Moorgreen), a Gibralter company with offices in\r     Spain; and a Moorgreen representative, Raymond Nakachian.  For additional\r     information, see litigation release numbers 15568 (November 21, 1997) and\r     15592 (December 12, 1997).\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15622 / January 21, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. Daniel E. Schneider, et al.,  et.\r     al., Civil Action No. 98-CV-0014-D (USDC Wyo.)\r\r          The Commission announced today that it obtained an emergency\r     restraining order prohibiting the illegal sale of bonds, purportedly backed\r     by gold, issued in the 19th century by the now defunct Chicago, Saginaw and\r     Canada Railroad Co. (Saginaw).  These bonds, according to the complaint,\r     are worthless as investments, having value only as historical memorabilia. \r     The order also prohibited the fraudulent sale of interests in a prime bank-\r     type trading program.  Judge William F. Downes entered his temporary\r     restraining order on January 20, 1998, against Daniel E. Schneider\r     (Schneider), a resident of Worland, Wyoming, and related entities Global\r     American Prosperity Foundation (GAPF) and Financial Sovereign Acquisition\r     Trust (FAST).  The Order also granted a freeze of assets held by Schneider,\r     GAPF and FAST, an accounting and repatriation of assets.  The Commission\s\r     complaint alleged that during 1997, Schneider, GAPF and FAST raised a total\r     of at least $2 million from six, and possibly more than 30, investors\r     nationwide through the sale of Saginaw bonds and through a bank debenture\r     trading program in which the Saginaw bonds or other assets purportedly\r     could be used to generate substantial returns.\r\r          Schneider, GAPF and FAST represented that the Saginaw bonds, which\r     were offered at $40,000 each, were backed by gold bullion and worth up to\r     $100 million each and that investors would receive at least a 30 percent\r     return on their investment.  In offering interests in the  trading program,\r     Schneider, GAPF and FAST represented that top world bank debentures\r     existed and traded in a legitimate market, investors would receive returns\r     of at least 15 percent per month, and investor funds would be invested in a\r     trading program.  Schneider, GAPF and FAST misrepresented, among other\r     things, the value of the Saginaw bonds, which in fact have only nominal\r     value as historical memorabilia.  Schneider, GAPF and FAST also\r     misrepresented the existence of prime bank-type securities, rates of return\r     investors were to receive, and the use of investor proceeds.  Schneider\r     diverted more than $196,000 of investor funds to purchase real estate or\r     for other personal uses.  The Commission alleged that through their false\r     and misleading statements, Schneider, GAPF and FAST violated the antifraud\r     provisions, Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b)\r     of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  \r\r          In the temporary restraining order, Judge Downes also ordered two\r     named relief defendants, California resident Norman Fadel (Fadel) and Utah\r     resident Ken Karlson (Karlson) to freeze assets derived from the fraud of\r     Schneider, GAPF and FAST.  Fadel and Karlson received approximately $96,000\r     and $354,000, respectively, from Schneider, GAPF and FAST.  The Commission\r     requested the \r\r                                  - 2 -\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     emergency action to prevent Schneider, GAPF, FAST, Fadel and Karlson from\r     transferring or liquidating any funds.\r\r          This fraud was uncovered initially by the Securities Division of the\r     Wyoming Secretary of State\s Office which worked closely with the\r     Commission in obtaining emergency relief.  The Commission wishes to thank\r     the Wyoming Secretary of State\s Securities Division for its assistance in\r     this matter.  \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15623 / January 22, 1998\r\r     SEC V. INSNET WORLD COMMUNICATIONS, INC., ET AL\r     H-97-2525 (USDC/ND TX Houston Division)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) announced that\r     on December 22, 1997, the Honorable Sim Lake, United States District Judge,\r     entered an Order of Permanent Injunction and Other Equitable Relief by\r     Default against defendant SCB Resources, Inc. (SCB) and ordered\r     disgorgement in the amount of $533,272.00 together with prejudgment\r     interest in the amount of $69,759.83.  Additionally, on January 9, 1998,\r     Judge Lake entered Orders of Permanent Injunction and Other Equitable\r     Relief by Default against Insnet World Communications, Inc. (Insnet),\r     Jose Manuel Diaz-Salin (Salin) and Scofield Berthelot, Jr. (Berthelot). \r     Judge Lake ordered disgorgement to be paid as follows:  Insnet was ordered\r     to pay $4,919,436.00, jointly and severally with the other defendants, with\r     prejudgment interest in the amount of $532,945.66; Salin was ordered to pay\r     $1,386,473.55 with prejudgment interest in the amount of $131,298.80; and\r     Berthelot was ordered to pay $32,600.00 with prejudgment interest in the\r     amount of $3,622.75.\r\r          The Commission charged in its Complaint, initially filed as a\r     temporary restraining order on July 28, 1997, against Insnet, SCB Salin,\r     Berthelot, Frank Bravo, Jr. (Bravo), and Eduardo Eddie Grijalva\r     (Grijalva), that the defendants violated Sections 5(a), 5(c) and 17(a) of\r     the Securities Act of 1933, and Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange\r     Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The Commission sought emergency\r     relief in the form of a temporary restraining order, asset freeze,\r     preliminary and permanent injunctions, and other relief.  Grijalva, Bravo\s\r     nephew, was named as a defendant solely for the purpose of relief.  \r\r          The Commission\s Complaint alleged that the defendants were engaged in\r     an ongoing fraudulent offer and sale of unregistered securities in the form\r     of promissory notes issued by Insnet, the proceeds of which were\r     purportedly used to purchase bulk long distance telephone time from major\r     satellite suppliers and directly distribute prepaid telephone calling cards\r     to the public.  It is further alleged that, since October 1995 to the\r     present, the defendants have fraudulently raised at least $4.8 million from\r     the sale of such securities to at least 216 investors residing in\r     approximately 38 states.  Moreover, instead of using the funds to purchase\r     long distance telephone time and distribute telephone calling cards as\r     represented, the Complaint alleges that at least $2.8 million of investor\r     funds have been paid to the individual defendants or companies that they\r     control.  The Complaint also indicated that investors have received Ponzi\r     payments when investment funds from later investors were used to make\r     quarterly interest payments and to repay investors when their notes\r     matured. \r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          Securities and Exchange Commission\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r     Litigation Release No.15624 / January 22, 1998\r     Accounting and Auditing Enforcement Release No. 1006\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. RUSSELL C. FAUST, United States\r     District Court for the Northern District of California, Civil Action No.\r     98-0197-CAL; UNITED STATES OF AMERICA v. RUSSELL C. FAUST\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing on\r     January 20, 1998 of both criminal and civil actions against Russell Faust,\r     formerly Chief Operating Officer and a Director of Media Vision Technology,\r     Inc. of Fremont, California, for his involvement in the fraudulent\r     reporting of Media Visions 1993 financial results to the public.\r\r          Faust has settled both the criminal and civil actions, which were\r     filed today in the Northern District of California.  As part of the\r     settlements, he has agreed to cooperate with authorities in their\r     continuing investigations into securities fraud by senior management at\r     Media Vision in 1993 and 1994.   Pursuant to a plea agreement with the U.S.\r     Attorneys office, Faust has agreed to plead guilty to one count of mail\r     fraud, which carries a potential prison sentence of five (5) years, a\r     $250,000 fine, and restitution to the victims of the fraud.  In the SEC\r     case, Faust, without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC\r     complaint, has consented to the entry of a Final Judgment requiring him to\r     pay $555,932, consisting of disgorgement of insider trading profits and\r     prejudgment interest in the amount of $197,285, an insider trading penalty\r     in the amount of $158,647 and an additional $200,000 in civil penalties,\r     barring him from serving as an officer or director of any public company,\r     and enjoining him from future violations of Section 17(a) of the Securities\r     Act of 1933, Sections 10(b) and 13(b)(5) of the Securities Exchange Act of\r     1934, and Rules 10b-5 and 13b2-2 thereunder.\r\r          The criminal information and the SEC complaint charge that Faust\r     participated in fraud at Media Vision by directing the falsification of\r     documents to make it appear that product had shipped in one quarter, when\r     in fact it had not shipped until the following quarter, for the purpose of\r     inflating revenues.  The SEC complaint also charges that Faust\r     misrepresented to auditors that Media Vision had no unrecognized product\r     returns and that Faust sold Media Vision stock while in possession of\r     material nonpublic information about fraud at the company.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r               SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                        Washington, D.C.\r\rLitigation Release No. 15625 / January 22, 1998\r\rSECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. William M. Fromm, Civil\rAction No. 98-0092-CV-W-3 (W.D. Mo. filed Jan. 22, 1998)\r\r     The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) has\rfiled a complaint in the United States District Court for the\rWestern District of Missouri against William M. Fromm (Fromm)\rin which the Commission alleges that Fromm traded in the common\rstock of Purolator Products Company (Purolator) while in\rpossession of material, nonpublic information about Purolator,\rand provided advice concerning Purolator to two individuals who\rtraded, prior to the October 3, 1994 announcement that Purolator\rand Mark IV Industries, Inc. (Mark IV) had entered into a\rdefinitive merger agreement.  Without admitting or denying any of\rthe allegations in the complaint, except as to jurisdiction,\rFromm consented to the entry of a final judgment enjoining him\rfrom violating sections 10(b) and 14(e) of the Securities\rExchange Act of 1934 (Exchange Act) and Exchange Act rules 10b-\r5 and 14e-3, ordering him to disgorge $213,750, plus prejudgment\rinterest on $13,750 of that amount of $4,076.36, and ordering him\rto pay a civil penalty of $13,750.\r\r     According to the complaint, based upon 1) information that\rFromm learned during a May 1994 meeting with the President and\rExecutive Vice President of Dayco Products, Inc., a Mark IV\rsubsidiary and client of the advertising, public relations, and\rconsulting firm of which Fromm was President and Chief Executive\rOfficer (CEO), 2) information that Fromm learned during a\rSeptember 1994 conversation with Mark IV\s Chairman and CEO at\revents related to a funeral, and 3) the previously publicly\rdisclosed information of the resignation of Mark IV\s CEO from\rPurolator\s Board of Directors, Fromm formed the belief that Mark\rIV was likely to acquire Purolator.  Also according to the\rCommission\s complaint, Fromm subsequently purchased a total of\r2,000 shares of Purolator common stock and advised two\rindividuals, who traded when it was reasonably foreseeable that\rthey would do so, of his belief that Mark IV was likely to\racquire Purolator.  The Commission alleges in its complaint that,\rin so doing, Fromm misappropriated material, nonpublic\rinformation that he obtained during the May 1994 meeting and the\rSeptember 1994 conversation in breach of a fiduciary duty or\rsimilar relationship of trust and confidence that he owed to\rDayco and Mark IV.\r\r     Following the public announcement of the Mark IV/Purolator\rtransaction, Fromm sold the 2,000 shares that he had purchased\rand realized a profit of $13,750.  Accounts of the two\rindividuals sold the shares that they had purchased and realized\rprofits of $608,750 and $687.50 respectively.\r\r     The Commission acknowledges the assistance of the National\rAssociation of Securities Dealers, Inc. in this matter.\r

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15626 / January 28, 1998\r\r     Securities and Exchange Commission v. Atlantic Capital Corporation, Wall\r     Street Marketing, Inc., Pullman Publications, Inc., Stephen DeCesare, Mark\r     Missler, Patrick Kephart, Howard Jenkins, Scott Mijares, Robert Thomas\r     Beatty, Vincent St. Clair Beatty, Michael Cardascia, David Scott Rossman,\r     Adrian Wilson, Timothy B. Daley, and David M. Connochie (M.D. Fla.) No. 96-\r     1043-CIV-ORL-19A \r\r          The Commission announced today that two stock promoters, previously\r     charged with paying kickbacks to brokers for selling certain securities to\r     their clients, have settled the charges against them.  On September 27,\r     1996, the Commission filed a Complaint in U.S. District Court for the\r     Middle District of Florida alleging that a group of stock promoters engaged\r     in an 18-month fraudulent scheme in which they paid $477,580 in bribes to\r     seven stockbrokers to induce them to retail securities to the public.  The\r     Complaint further alleged that the stock promoters issued promotional\r     brochures concerning various public companies without disclosing that they\r     were being paid by the companies to issue the brochures.  The Complaint\r     alleges that the promoters netted approximately $2.6 million from the\r     scheme.\r\r          The settling stock promoters are:\r\r          Patrick Kephart (Kephart), age 33, formerly of Apopka, Florida.\r\r          Scott Mijares  (Mijares ), age 37, formerly of Winter Park,\r          Florida.\r\r          Kephart and Mijares consented, without admitting or denying the\r     allegations in the Complaint, to the issuance of a Final Judgment by Judge\r     Patricia C. Fawsett of the United States District Court for the Middle\r     District of Florida enjoining each from future violations of Sections 17(a)\r     and 17(b) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities\r     Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5.  Kephart also consented to disgorge\r     $25,297.88 in profits he received from the alleged scheme, plus $11,910.71\r     in prejudgment interest and to pay a penalty of $25,297.88.  Mijares\r     consented to disgorge $19,002.00 in profits he received from the alleged\r     scheme, plus $8,946.50 in prejudgment interest and to pay a penalty of\r     $19,002.00.\r\r          The Commission s litigation is still pending against four brokers and\r     one other stock promoter.\r\r     For further information See Litigation Release No. 15082, September 27,\r     1996, Litigation Release No. 15428, August 4, 1997, and Litigation Release\r     No. 15532, October 10, 1997. \r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15627 / January 28, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. TRINITY GAS CORPORATION AND SIDNEY W.\r     SERS\r     Civil Action No. 4:97-CV-1018-Y, (N.D. TX, Fort Worth Division)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that on January 26,\r     1998, the Honorable Terry R. Means, United States District Judge, held\r     Sidney W. Sers (Sers), defendant in this civil injunctive action, in\r     civil contempt of a Temporary Restraining Order, entered December 9, 1997,\r     and an Order of Preliminary Injunction, entered January 6, 1998, regarding\r     the freezing of assets.  Judge Means ordered that a warrant be issued for\r     Sers\ arrest and that he be placed in confinement until he turns over to\r     the Court certain monies, and returns $800,000 removed from Trinity\r     Colombia, a defendant named solely for purposes of relief, for immediate\r     repatriation to the United States.\r\r          In a related action, In Re Trinity Gas Corporation filed on December\r     23, 1997, in the United States Bankruptcy Court, Case No. 97-60245-JCA-11\r     (N.D. Tex, San Angelo Division), the Bankruptcy Court has appointed Henry\r     C. Seals as Chapter 11 Trustee for the Trinity Gas bankruptcy estate.  On\r     January 12, 1998, the Trustee took physical possession of the business\r     offices of Trinity Gas.\r\r          The civil injunctive action was instituted on December 8, 1997,\r     against Trinity Gas Corporation and Mr. Sers, alleging fraud in connection\r     with the sale by Trinity Gas of approximately $11 million of Trinity stock\r     to at least 250 investors residing in 13 states; and the sale, on his own\r     behalf and on behalf of certain family members, of at least $5.8 million of\r     Trinity Gas securities by means of the NASDAQ Bulletin Board and additional\r     shares by means of unlicensed salesmen.  See Litigation Release No. 15582,\r     December 8, 1997.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15628 / January 28, 1998\r\r     Securities and Exchange Commission v. J.W. Korth & Co. and James Wilder\r     Korth., Case No. 97-0280-Civ-Ungaro-Benages (USDC/SD FL)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) announced that on\r     January 22, 1998, the Honorable Ursula Ungaro-Benages, United States\r     District Judge for the Southern District of Florida, granted the SEC\s\r     motion and entered summary judgment against J.W. Korth & Co., a Miami,\r     Florida broker-dealer, and its president James Wilder Korth.  The judge\r     ruled that Korth and his firm violated the securities laws by repeatedly\r     refusing to give the SEC the serial numbers for defaulted pre-World War II\r     German Bonds they were selling.  The SEC had alleged that Korth was hiding\r     the information from it and that, without the numbers, the SEC could not\r     determine whether sales of the bonds violated the federal securities laws.\r\r          Earlier in the case, the SEC had sought and obtained a temporary\r     restraining order (TRO) ordering Korth to give the SEC the numbers. \r     Korth refused to do so, and was quoted in a Miami Herald article as saying\r     that he was going to stand firm and not produce any numbers.  Korth\r     finally turned over the numbers after a February 1997 hearing during which\r     the judge granted the SEC\s request for a preliminary injunction and\r     ordered him to do so or face a contempt citation.\r\r          In entering final judgment against Korth and his firm, the judge noted\r     that they had failed to comply with the TRO, openly and publicly defied\r     it, and only turned over the numbers after the Court indicated its view\r     that those actions were contumacious and that civil and criminal contempt\r     citations were imminent.
