Based on their violation of the law and this\r     conduct, the judge permanently enjoined Korth and the firm from future\r     violations of the relevant provision, Section 17 of the Securities Exchange\r     Act of 1934, and imposed first-tier penalties of $55,000 and $5,500 on the\r     firm and Korth respectively.\r\r          The case appears to be the first time a broker-dealer has been\r     penalized for failing to comply with the SEC\s statutory examination\r     powers.  In her opinion, the judge recognized the SEC\s vital role in\r     regulating the securities markets, and ruled that the SEC right to examine\r     a registered broker-dealer is central to the execution of [its] congress-\r     ionally-mandated regulatory duties.  As such, the judge ruled that the\r     SEC\s examination powers are subject only to reasonable time, place and\r     manner restrictions.\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15629 / January  29, 1998\r\r     Accounting and Auditing Enforcement\r     Release No. 1008 / January 29, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. DONALD FERRARINI, BRUNO RUMIGNANI,\r     HOWARD MILLER, MARK BAILINE, and FRANK PALUMBO, 98 Civ. 0629 (SWK)\r     (S.D.N.Y. January 29, 1998)\r\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it filed a\r     civil injunctive action in federal court in Manhattan charging five former\r     officers of a now bankrupt insurance brokerage firm with engaging in a\r     financial fraud for more than two years.  As a result of the defendants\\r     conduct, the insurance brokerage falsely reported to the public that it had\r     been profitable in 1993 and 1994, when it had actually sustained losses in\r     those years.  The Commission\s complaint also alleges that one of the\r     defendants engaged in illegal insider trading. \r\r     Named in the Commission\s complaint were:\r\r          Donald Ferrarini (Ferrarini), age 69, who was chief executive\r     officer, president and chairman of the board of directors of Underwriters\r     Financial Group, Inc. (UFG) during the time of the events relating to the\r     financial fraud alleged in the complaint.\r\r          Bruno Rumignani (Rumignani), age 55, who was UFG\s executive vice\r     president and a director during the time of the events relating to the\r     financial fraud alleged in the complaint.\r\r          Howard Miller (Miller), age 66, who was UFG\s senior vice president\r     and a director during the time of the events relating to the financial\r     fraud alleged in the complaint.  Miller was previously an officer of BRI\r     Holding Corp. (BRI), a private company that merged with Chippewa\r     Resources Corp. (Chippewa) in 1992 to form UFG.\r\r          Mark Bailine (Bailine), age 47, who was UFG\s vice president of\r     finance and administration during the time of the events relating to the\r     financial fraud alleged in the complaint.  \r\r          Frank Palumbo (Palumbo), age 51, who was UFG\s controller during the\r     time of the events relating to the financial fraud alleged in the\r     complaint.  \r\r     The Commission\s complaint alleges that between 1993 and 1995, Ferrarini,\r     Rumignani, Miller, Bailine and Palumbo engaged in a \r\r                                        - 2 -\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     fraudulent scheme whereby UFG fraudulently obtained money from companies\r     with which UFG did business and, by making fictitious and other improper\r     entries on UFG\s books and records, improperly included those fraudulently\r     obtained funds as legitimate income.  The complaint alleges that defendants\r     employed two fraudulent practices to obtain cash and misrepresent UFG\s\r     financial performance to the public: (i) a premium finance fraud, whereby\r     UFG recorded as income money that UFG had fraudulently obtained from\r     companies that finance insurance premiums and recorded proceeds of the\r     fraud as income; and (ii) an accounts payable fraud, whereby UFG\r     improperly deleted certain outstanding accounts payable and improperly\r     recorded corresponding amounts as income.  According to the complaint, as\r     part of the premium finance fraud, UFG sought and obtained financing for\r     insurance premiums on behalf of customers who did not need or request such\r     financing, and the proceeds of the financing were instead used to pay UFG\s\r     operating expenses and for other purposes.  The defendants also made\r     material misstatements to UFG\s auditors.  \r\r     As a result of this conduct, the annual and quarterly reports that UFG\r     filed with the Commission and disseminated to the public for 1993 and 1994,\r     and the quarters ended March 31, 1994, June 30, 1994 and September 30,\r     1994, falsely portray UFG as profitable when, in fact, it had incurred\r     substantial losses.  Although UFG reported a loss for the quarter ended\r     March 31, 1995, UFG materially understated that loss due to the defendants\\r     conduct.  \r\r     The complaint also alleges that Miller unlawfully purchased securities of\r     Chippewa while he possessed material nonpublic information about the merger\r     between Chippewa and BRI.  Specifically, the complaint alleges that in\r     August 1992, Miller, an officer of BRI, purchased 11,000 shares of Chippewa\r     common stock when Miller knew of that pending merger.\r\r     As a result of the foregoing, the complaint alleges that Ferrarini,\r     Rumignani and Miller violated antifraud and corporate reporting,\r     recordkeeping and other provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934\r     (Exchange Act), and that Bailine and Palumbo violated antifraud and other\r     provisions of the Exchange Act. \r\r     In the complaint, the Commission seeks:  permanent injunctions and civil\r     penalties against all defendants; disgorgement from Miller of his illegal\r     trading profits and prejudgment interest thereon; and officer and director\r     bars against Ferrarini, Rumignani and Miller.\r\r     In February 1996, Bailine pled guilty to two felony counts, including\r     conspiracy to commit securities fraud, in connection with the conduct\r     alleged in the complaint.  United States v. Bailine, 96 Cr. 17 (LLS)\r     (S.D.N.Y. Feb. 5, 1996).  In October \r\r                                         - 3 -\r\r     1996, Palumbo pled guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit, inter alia,\r     securities fraud, in connection with the conduct alleged in the complaint. \r     United States v. Palumbo, 96 Cr. 816 (MGC) (S.D.N.Y.) (Oct. 3, 1996).\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     Simultaneous with the filing of this complaint, Palumbo consented, without\r     admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, to the issuance of a\r     final judgment permanently enjoining him from committing future violations\r     of Sections 10(b) and 13(b)(5) of the Exchange Act and Rules 10b-5, 13b2-1\r     and 13b2-2.  Palumbo also agreed to pay a civil money penalty of $10,000.\r\r     The litigation is pending against Ferrarini, Rumignani, Miller and Bailine.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 3======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15630 / January 29 , 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. JAMES PANNONE AND SAKURA GLOBAL\r     CAPITAL, INC., United States District Court for the Western District of\r     Oklahoma, Civ 98-146L\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that on January 29,\r     1998, it filed a Complaint in the United States District Court for the\r     Western District of Oklahoma against James Pannone, a former vice president\r     of the Oklahoma Public Finance Office of Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Inc.\r     (Stifel), a broker-dealer registered with the Commission, and Sakura\r     Global Capital, Inc. (Sakura), a subsidiary of Sakura Bank that is\r     engaged in the business of selling derivatives.  The Complaint alleges that\r     the defendants committed fraud in connection with the sale of municipal\r     securities.  The Complaint alleges that in two municipal bond transactions\r     underwritten by Stifel, Pannone engaged in bid-rigging to ensure Sakura\s\r     selection as the provider of the forward purchase agreements (forwards)\r     to the issuers.  The Complaint also alleges that in those same securities\r     transactions, Pannone and Sakura made materially misleading statements\r     and/or affirmative misrepresentations to the issuers with respect to\r     undisclosed payments that Sakura made to Stifel.  The Complaint alleges\r     that these undisclosed payments jeopardized the tax-exempt status of the\r     bonds.\r\r          The Complaint alleges that in a 1992 transaction for the Oklahoma\r     Turnpike Authority, despite bond counsel\s requirement that three\r     competitive bids be obtained for the forward, Pannone rigged the bidding to\r     ensure Sakura\s selection as the forward provider.  The Complaint also\r     alleges that Pannone subsequently negotiated with Steven Strauss, Sakura s\r     then managing director in charge of municipal securities transactions, a\r     $6.593 million undisclosed brokerage fee to be paid by Sakura to Stifel,\r     and that Pannone falsely described to the Turnpike Authority the bidding\r     and negotiation process of the forward.  The Complaint further alleges that\r     the forward purchase agreement stated that Sakura did not intend to take\r     any actions which would jeopardize the tax-exempt status of the bonds.  The\r     Complaint alleges that at the time Sakura executed the forward it was\r     planning to pay a $6.593 million brokerage fee to Stifel, and that Sakura\r     knew or was reckless in not knowing that such a brokerage fee would\r     jeopardize the tax-exempt status of the bonds.  \r\r          The Complaint also alleges that in a 1992 transaction for the Sisters\r     of St. Mary\s Health Care Obligated Group, despite bond counsel\s\r     requirement that three competitive bids be obtained for the forward,\r     Pannone rigged the bidding to ensure Sakura\s selection as the forward\r     provider.  The Complaint further alleges that at the request of bond\r     counsel, Pannone and Strauss provided certificates stating that Sakura\r     would not make any payments, other than certain payments to the issuer, in\r     connection with the forward.  The Complaint alleges that Sakura made a\r     $100,000 payment to Stifel and that Pannone concealed the payment by\r     booking it to a different transaction. \r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r          The Complaint alleges that by their conduct, Pannone and Sakura\r     violated Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, Section 10(b) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (Exchange Act) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder,\r     and that Pannone also violated Section 15B(c)(1) of the Exchange Act and\r     Rule G-17 of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board.  The Complaint\r     seeks relief including a permanent injunction barring Pannone and Sakura\r     from future violations of those provisions and the imposition of civil\r     monetary penalties.\r\r          The Commission previously sued Stifel, Robert Cochran, Stifel\s former\r     executive vice president in charge of its Oklahoma Public Finance Office,\r     and Steven Strauss in connection with these transactions.  The Commission\r     settled its action against Stifel.  The Commission\s litigation is ongoing\r     with respect to Cochran and Strauss.  See Lit. Rel. No. 15569 (Nov. 24,\r     1997); Lit. Rel. No. 14644 (Sept. 20, 1995); and Lit. Rel. No. 14587 (Aug.\r     3, 1995). \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   United States Securities and Exchange Commission\r\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15631 / January 29, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. MIKO LEUNG (a/k/a LEUNG MING KANG)\r     AND SIT WA LEUNG, U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, Civil\r     Action No. 98-00233 (TFH)(D.D.C.)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed a Complaint in the\r     United States District Court for the District of Columbia against Miko\r     Leung (Miko), 54, the former chairman and president of MTC Electronic\r     Technologies, Inc. (MTC), a British Columbia importer of consumer\r     electronics (now known as Grandetel Technologies, Inc.) which traded on\r     NASDAQ, and his brother Sit Wa Leung (Sit Wa), 62, MTC\s former corporate\r     secretary and a member of its board of directors.  The Complaint alleges\r     that between 1990 and 1993, the defendants engaged in a false disclosure\r     and accounting fraud scheme that culminated in a pump and dump stock\r     manipulation, and that they unjustly enriched themselves by more than $16\r     million by selling MTC stock, including approximately 1.5 million shares\r     they had stolen.  The Commission is seeking permanent injunctions against\r     both defendants; disgorgement of their ill-gotten gains; civil penalties\r     and officer and director bars against them.  \r\r          In a related matter the Commission issued a Cease-And-Desist Order\r     (Order) against Ronald W. Driol.  Without admitting or denying the\r     Commission\s findings, Driol consented to the issuance of the Order which\r     finds, among other things, that while he was employed at the Hongkong Bank\r     of Canada in Vancouver and managing MTC\s accounts, he assisted the\r     defendants\ scheme by placing Hongkong Bank of Canada\s signature guarantee\r     on stolen stock certificates, and thereafter approving transactions in\r     which proceeds were transferred through nominee bank accounts at that bank. \r       \r\r          Specifically, the Complaint against Miko and Sit Wa alleges the\r     following:\r\r          Between 1990 and 1993, MTC claimed that it had developed a new\r     telecommunications business in the People\s Republic of China (PRC)\r     including agreements that made it the exclusive supplier of fax machines to\r     the PRC, and joint venture projects to provide telecommunications services\r     in various cities in the PRC.  For each of its fiscal years 1991 through\r     1993, MTC falsely claimed that it had received millions of dollars in\r     revenues from the fax machine sales, accounting for from 31 to 46 percent\r     of its total revenues.  In fact, MTC sold no fax machines in the PRC, and\r     Miko deceived MTC\s independent accountants by providing them with false\r     documentation to support the fictitious sales.  In 1991, at Miko\s\r     direction, MTC similarly began misrepresenting that it had concluded joint\r     venture agreements that would make it the exclusive supplier of cellular\r     telephone service to Shanghai and other major cities in the PRC.  After\r     disseminating this false information Miko and Sit Wa started selling MTC\r     stock through nominee accounts they controlled.  \r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r          Between February and August 1992, Miko induced MTC\s board to issue\r     below market options on 1.52 million shares of MTC ostensibly to be used as\r     incentives for existing and prospective MTC employees.  In fact, none of\r     the intended recipients received the options.  Instead, the defendants\r     stole them; fraudulently exercised them; fraudulently endorsed the\r     certificates; and deposited the shares in nominee brokerage accounts they\r     controlled.\r\r          Between September and December 1992, Miko flooded the market with\r     additional false information, including the misrepresentation that as a\r     result of several new joint venture agreements MTC had the exclusive right\r     to provide cellular phone and/or paging services to approximately 300\r     million people, or 25% of the population of China.  As a result, MTC\s\r     stock price increased from $5 1/8 to $30.  The defendants simultaneously\r     sold the shares they had stolen at these artifically inflated prices,\r     realizing illegal profits of $12.1 million on those shares.  Their sales of\r     other MTC shares between May 1991 and September 1992 had unjustly enriched\r     them by in excess of another $4 million.  The defendants laundered the\r     proceeds of their illegal securities transactions through a series of bank\r     accounts world-wide, most of which were nominee accounts they controlled.\r\r          The Commission is seeking the entry of a final judgment (1)\r     permanently enjoining both defendants from violations of Section 17(a) of\r     the Securities Act of 1933, Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of\r     1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and also permanently enjoining Miko from\r     violations of Section 13(b)(5) of the Exchange Act, and Rules 13b2-1 and\r     13b2-2 thereunder; (2) ordering the defendants to disgorge their illegal\r     trading profits and losses illegally avoided, plus prejudgment interest;\r     (3) ordering them to pay civil penalties; and (4) permanently prohibiting\r     them from acting as officers or directors of any issuer that has a class of\r     securities registered pursuant to Section 12 of the Exchange Act, or that\r     is required to file reports pursuant to Section 15(d) of the Exchange Act.\r\r          In the Cease-And-Desist Order, the Commission found that Driol played\r     an indispensable role in facilitating the sale of the options stock stolen\r     by Miko and Sit Wa by placing Hongkong Bank of Canada\s signature guarantee\r     on the stolen MTC share certificates issued in the names of existing and\r     prospective MTC employees.  He did so in spite of the facts that none of\r     the nominal owners of the certificates were present when Driol guaranteed\r     their signatures, that he had not met or even heard of them before being\r     presented with the certificates, and that most, if not all, of the\r     certificates had not been signed when he placed the guarantees on them. \r     Because the certificates ultimately bore a signature authorizing their\r     transfer that purported to be that of the named owner and bore Hongkong\r     Bank of Canada\s signature guarantee, Miko and Sit Wa were able to sell the\r     shares through nominee brokerage accounts.  Thereafter Driol played a\r     central role in the transfer of the proceeds of the sale of that stolen\r     stock from the nominee brokerage accounts to other nominee bank accounts at\r     the Hongkong Bank of Canada, and the retransmission to still other nominee\r     bank accounts in Hong Kong.  Specifically, he wrote or approved the\r     transfer instructions for every wire transfer from these bank accounts\r     during the period September through December 1992, and approved several of\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     the deposits to these accounts from the nominee brokerage accounts.  Driol\r     knew, or was reckless in not knowing, that Miko controlled the nominee bank\r     accounts.  \r\r          The Commission found that as a result of that conduct Driol caused\r     violations of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act, Section 10(b) of the\r     Exchange Act, and Rule 10b-5 thereunder and ordered Driol to cease and\r     desist from further violations of these antifraud provisions.  In the\r     Matter of Ronald W. Driol, Administrative Proceeding File Number 3-9536.  \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 3======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                   Washington, D.C.\r\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15632 / January 30, 1998\r\r     Accounting and Auditing Enforcement\r     Release No. 1009\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. DONALD FERRARINI, BRUNO RUMIGNANI,\r     HOWARD MILLER, MARK BAILINE, and FRANK PALUMBO, 98 Civ. 0629 (SWK)\r     (S.D.N.Y. January 29, 1998)\r\r     The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that defendant Mark\r     Bailine (Bailine) consented to the entry of a final judgment against him\r     in SEC v. Donald Ferrarini, et al., a civil injunctive action filed\r     yesterday in federal court in Manhattan.\r\r     In its complaint, the Commission alleges that Bailine and the other\r     defendants engaged in a fraudulent scheme whereby they falsely portrayed\r     the financial condition of Underwriters Financial Group, Inc. (UFG), a\r     now bankrupt insurance brokerage firm, for the years ended December 31,\r     1993 and December 31, 1994 and the quarters ended March 31, 1994, June 30,\r     1994, September 31, 1994 and March 31, 1995.  The complaint also alleges\r     that Bailine and the other defendants, directly or indirectly, made false\r     entries on UFG\s books and records and made material misrepresentations to\r     UFG\s auditors.  At the time of the events alleged in the complaint,\r     Bailine was UFG\s vice president of finance and administration.\r\r     Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, Bailine\r     consented to the issuance of a final judgment permanently enjoining him\r     from committing future violations of Sections 10(b) and 13(b)(5) of the\r     Exchange Act and Rules 10b-5, 13b2-1 and 13b2-2.  Bailine also agreed to\r     pay a civil money penalty of $10,000.\r\r     For more information see Litigation Release No. 15629; Accounting and\r     Auditing Enforcement Release No. 1008.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15633 / January 30, 1998\r\r     Accounting and Auditing Enforcement\r     Release No. 1011 / January 30, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. JAMES PATRICK KITTLER \r     (Civ. No. 98-551DSD/JMM) January 30, 1998\r\r     The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it filed, and\r     simultaneously settled, a civil suit in federal court in the District of\r     Minnesota against J. Patrick Kittler, trustee and chief executive officer\r     of National Trade Trust, a Minneapolis, Minnesota company.  The complaint\r     alleges that under Kittlers direction the company disseminated misleading\r     offering materials that misrepresented the safety and liquidity of the\r     companys promissory notes.  These offering materials included fraudulent\r     financial statements that materially overstated the companys earnings,\r     assets and net worth.  The complaint further alleges that these financial\r     statements, prepared at Kittler s direction, (i) artificially inflated\r     assets by $2 million, by recording an asset which held no value for the\r     company; (ii) failed to record reserves for uncollectible loans; and (iii)\r     recorded advances to clients at inflated values, instead of the actual\r     amount advanced to each client.  Between February 1990 and March 1994, the\r     company raised approximately $8 million from over 300 investors from the\r     sale of its notes.  National Trade Trust has defaulted on the notes and\r     currently owes approximately $6.5 million to over 200 investors.  The\r     company has ceased operations and is liquidating its remaining assets.\r\r     The complaint alleges that by preparing the fraudulent financial\r     statements, Kittler violated Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933,\r     Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Rule 10b-5\r     thereunder.  Kittler has consented, without admitting or denying the\r     Commission s allegations, to the entry of an order of permanent injunction\r     and the payment of a $25,000 civil penalty. \r\r     The Commission also instituted, and simultaneously settled, administrative\r     proceedings against the companys independent auditor, Paul Mount.  Mount\r     consented to the entry of an order barring him from appearing or practicing\r     before the Commission as an accountant for four years.  Mount, through his\r     accounting firm, Mount & Borresen, Ltd., of Bloomington, Minnesota, audited\r     the companys financial statements for the fiscal years ended December 31,\r     1990, 1991 and 1992.  These financial statements, together with audit\r     reports prepared by Mount, were included in the company s offering\r     statements filed with the Commission under Regulation A of the Securities\r     Act of 1933.\r\r     The administrative order, which Mount consented to without admitting or\r     denying, finds that Mount engaged in improper professional conduct by\r     failing to obtain sufficient competent evidential matter to support his\r     opinions, by failing to exercise due professional care, and by lacking the\r     proper degree of professional skepticism.  \r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15634 / February 3, 1998\r\r     Securities and Exchange Commission v. First Zurich National U.S.A., LLC and\r     Compunomics 139, Inc. Civil Action No. 98-CV-29D  (USDC Wy.) \r\r          On February 2, 1998, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the\r     Commission) filed an emergency action seeking to halt an affinity fraud\r     being promoted over the internet and targeting African Americans.  On\r     February 3, 1998, the Commission obtained a temporary restraining order,\r     including an asset freeze, from the United States District Court for the\r     District of Wyoming against First Zurich National U.S.A., LLC (First\r     Zurich), a Wyoming limited liability company (LLC) and Compunomics 139,\r     Inc. (Compunomics), a Belizean corporation based in southern California\r     and the corporate parent of First Zurich.  The Commission has received\r     substantial assistance in this case from the California Department of\r     Corporations, the Wyoming State Securities Division and the Cheyenne,\r     Wyoming office of the United States Postal Inspection Service.\r\r          Compunomics has been offering and selling First Zurich stock since at\r     least April 1997, which Compunomics claims has been operating as a global\r     internet bank since November 1997.  The Commission alleges that First\r     Zurich and Compunomics have failed to disclose to prospective and current\r     investors that First Zurich cannot legally operate as a bank.  The Office\r     of the Comptroller of the Currency has not granted a national bank charter\r     to First Zurich nor has the Wyoming State Banking Board authorized First\r     Zurich to conduct banking operations.  Moreover, First Zurich, as a Wyoming\r     LLC, is not permitted under Wyoming corporate law to conduct banking\r     operations.\r\r          The Commission further alleges that Compunomics has been offering and\r     selling First Zurich stock to its current shareholders and has made a sales\r     presentation to a national church conference attended by approximately\r     30,000 individuals.  Compunomics is promoting First Zurich on the internet,\r     as well as through written materials and promotional meetings.  The\r     Commission alleges that the defendants are seeking to raise $60 million\r     from 5,000 investors over a ten-year period and are currently receiving a\r     minimum of between $50,000 and $75,000 per month from at least 500 and\r     possibly as many as 750 investors nationwide.  Investors have signed option\r     agreements obligating them to purchase a fixed amount of First Zurich\s\r     stock for $1.25 per share by making an initial $98 payment and then monthly\r     minimum payments of $99 for ten years, representing a total investment of\r     $11,978 per investor. \r\r          The Commission\s complaint charges that the defendants \r     have violated the antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws --\r     Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. \r\r          Investors are again advised to read the SEC\s Cyberspace Alert\r     before purchasing any investment promoted on the internet.  The free\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     publication, which alerts investors to the telltale signs of online\r     investment fraud, is available on the Investor Assistance and Complaints\r     link of the SEC\s Home page on the World Wide Web <www.sec.gov>. It can\r     also be obtained by calling 800-SEC-0330.\r\r          Investors are encouraged to report suspicious internet offerings (or\r     other suspicious offerings) via e-mail to <enforcement@sec.gov>.  A user-\r     friendly form to assist you in making a report is available at the\r     Enforcement Complaint Center on the Enforcement Division link of the SEC\r     Home Page.  Investors can also mail a report to the SEC\s Enforcement\r     Complaint Center, Mail Stop 8-4, 450 Fifth Street, N.W., Washington, D.C.\r     20549.  \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15635 / February 5, 1998\r\r     United States of America v. Roger E. Turner, USDC/ND TX (Dallas Division),\r     397-CR-427-G\r\r     The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that on January 13, 1998,\r     Roger E. Turner, who operated a Grand Prairie, Texas investment adviser,\r     Annable Turner & Company, Inc., pled guilty to violating the antifraud\r     provisions of the Securities Act of 1933.  It is alleged that, from at\r     least January 1990 through January 1997, Turner falsely represented to\r     investors that he would invest their funds, at times through newly opened\r     IRAs, in safe, solvent investments, upon which investors would receive a\r     substantial return. In fact, Turner neither purchased the securities nor\r     opened the IRAs.  Instead, he misapplied investor funds, and hid his\r     misapplications by providing investors with false portfolio statements.\r     Investors are alleged to have suffered losses of between $1.5 and $2.5\r     million.\r\r     A sentencing hearing is set for March 24, 1998, before the Honorable A. Joe\r     Fish, United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas.\r     Turner and the United States Attorney for the Northern District of Texas\r     have also agreed to a non-binding stipulation under which the Court can\r     impose a term of 24 to 37 months imprisonment. Turners plea agreement also\r     notes that the Court can impose fines, supervised release terms, special\r     assessments and restitution.\r\r     The Fort Worth District Office of the Commission assisted the United States\r     Attorney with the criminal investigation.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                       U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15636 / February 5, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. D\ACQUISTO FINANCIAL GROUP, INC., et\r     al., Civil Action No. 95-1105 BTM (AJB) (S.D. Cal.)\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that on January 28,\r     1998, the Honorable Barry T. Moskowitz United States District Judge of the\r     Southern District of California entered a final judgment against Thomas F.\r     Goodman.  The Court held Thomas F. Goodman, an attorney, liable for\r     securities fraud and ordered him to pay $99,500 in disgorgement and\r     $22,140.49 in prejudgment interest jointly and severally with his co-\r     defendants John F. D\Acquisto, Doubleday Trust, and D\Acquisto Financial\r     Group, Inc.  The Court found that an injunction should issue against\r     Goodman, barring him from future violations of the securities laws.  In\r     reaching its decision, the Court found that Goodman principally\r     participated in the fraud when he prepared and issued prospectuses that\r     promoted the fraudulent schemes in clear violation of the law.  The\r     fraudulent schemes involved the sale of $7,000,000 worth of inherently\r     fraudulent prime bank securities. \r\r          Goodman, along with D\Acquisto, sold the fraudulent securities through\r     Doubleday and D\Acquisto Financial Group from November 1993 through June\r     1994.  Goodman represented to investors that the prime bank securities\r     were entirely legal and the crown jewel of Doubleday\s investment\r     program.  Goodman made these representations without investigating whether\r     such securities actually existed.  The Court found that these\r     misrepresentations violated Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and\r     Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5\r     thereunder.\r\r          In earlier rulings, the Court found that D\Acquisto, Doubleday and\r     D\Acquisto Financial Group misrepresented to one investor that its $200,000\r     investment would be worth $1,833,565.64 in a week\s time; represented to\r     another investor that it would receive returns of 2% to 7.5% per week; and\r     represented to a third investor that it would receive returns of at least\r     80% per month.  The Court held Goodman\s co-defendants jointly and\r     severally liable for $6,780,000 in disgorgement and $641,471.27 in\r     prejudgment interest.  \r\r          In a recent administrative matter, the Securities and Exchange\r     Commission revoked D\Acquisto\s registration as an investment adviser and\r     barred him from associating with an investment adviser.  \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r          For further information, please see Litigation Release Nos. LR-14562,\r     LR-14681 and LR-15140.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15637 / February 5, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. JOHN G. BENNETT, JR. AND THE\r     FOUNDATION FOR NEW ERA PHILANTHROPY, 95 Civ. 3005, U.S.D.C., E.D.PA (AB)\r\r     The Securities and Exchange Commission (Commission) announced that, on\r     February 4, 1998, the Honorable Anita Brody, United States District Court\r     Judge for the Eastern District Of Pennsylvania, issued the Final Judgment\r     Of Permanent Injunction And Other Equitable Relief By Consent Against John\r     G. Bennett (Final Judgment), the founder and former president of the now\r     defunct Foundation For New Era Philanthropy (New Era).\r\r     The Complaint, which was filed on May 18, 1995, alleged, among other\r     things, that defendants John G. Bennett (Bennett) and New Era conducted a\r     fraudulent scheme in which hundreds of not-for-profit organizations,\r     charities, and individuals were promised that funds they invested in New\r     Era\s notes and investment contracts would be doubled in six months by\r     guaranteed monies that Bennett and New Era had secured from several very\r     wealthy anonymous benefactors.   The Complaint further alleged that\r     Bennett\s and New Era\s anonymous benefactors did not exist and that\r     Bennett and New Era made numerous other material misrepresentations and\r     omissions in the course of offering and selling their securities.  The\r     Complaint alleged that Bennett and New Era victimized hundreds of investors\r     throughout the nation, and wrongfully solicited more than $100 million\r     dollars in 1995 alone.  \r\r     The Court\s Final Judgment permanently enjoins Bennett from further\r     violating the registration and antifraud provisions of the securities laws. \r     The Final Judgment also orders Bennett to disgorge profits earned as a\r     result of the conduct alleged in the Complaint, plus interest, in the total\r     amount of $3,424,015, but waives payment based on Bennett\s demonstrated\r     inability to pay.\r     Bennett is currently serving a twelve year sentence in the federal\r     correctional institution in Fort Dix, New Jersey, pursuant to criminal\r     charges based, in large part, upon the same facts alleged in the\r     Commission\s Complaint.\r\r     The Commission also filed a notice voluntarily withdrawing its claims\r     against defendant New Era.  Since May 1995, New Era has been subject to\r     liquidation proceedings in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the\r     Eastern District of Pennsylvania.  In June 1996, with the Commission\s and\r     the Court\s approval, Bennett transferred nearly all of his assets to the\r     Bankruptcy Estate so that those funds could be distributed to defrauded\r     investors.  For further information see Lit. Rel. ## 14503, 14505, 14531 &\r     15095.\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15638 / February 9, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. NICHOLAS A. ZAHAREAS, TUSCHNER &\r     COMPANY, INC. and JOHN M. TUSCHNER, DEFENDANTS and EUROAMERICAN SECURITIES\r     S.A., RELIEF DEFENDANT, United States District Court for the District of\r     Minnesota, No. 97-2859 DSD/JMM\r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that a preliminary\r     injunction hearing was held before the Honorable David S. Doty of the U.S.\r     District Court for the District of Minnesota on January 20, 1998.  After\r     arguments of counsel, the Court issued a preliminary injunction against\r     Nicholas A. Zahareas (Zahareas), Tuschner & Company, Inc. (Tuschner & Co.)\r     and John M. Tuschner (Tuschner).  The preliminary injunction was based on\r     Zahareas association with Tuschner & Co., a Minneapolis broker-dealer, in\r     violation of a July 27, 1993 Commission order barring Zahareas from\r     associating with any registered broker, dealer, investment company,\r     investment adviser or municipal securities dealer.  Zahareas is also the\r     subject of an Order of Permanent Injunction, issued by consent against him\r     on July 16, 1992, prohibiting him from violating the antifraud provisions\r     of the federal securities laws. \r\r          In entering the preliminary injunction, the Court found that Zahareas\r     violated the Commissions bar order and wrongfully associated with a\r     registered broker-dealer, Tuschner & Co., by acting as a Tuschner & Co.\r     registered representative in all but name.  Zahareas acted as Tuschner &\r     Co.s registered representative by:  referring at least 200 customers\r     residing in Greece to Tuschner & Co.; directing trading in their accounts\r     at Tuschner & Co.; placing orders for over $9 million worth of securities\r     with Tuschner & Co.s trader; determining the amount of commissions charged\r     on the transactions; and receiving up to 75% of those commissions through\r     payments to Relief Defendant Euroamerican Securities S.A., a Greek\r     brokerage firm controlled by Zahareas.  In addition, the Court found that\r     Tuschner & Co. wrongfully allowed Zahareas to associate with it and that\r     Tuschner, the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Tuschner & Co., knew\r     of Zahareas bar from the securities industry and aided and abetted\r     Zahareas wrongful association with Tuschner & Co.\r\r          The preliminary injunction entered against Zahareas, Tuschner & Co.\r     and Tuschner restrained and enjoined them from, directly or indirectly,\r     violating and/or aiding and abetting violations of Sections 15(b)(6)(B)(i)\r     and 15(b)(6)(B)(ii) of the Exchange Act.  Action remains pending as to the\r     Commissions prayer for the entry of a permanent injunction, disgorgement\r     and civil penalties.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No.  15639 / February 10, 1998\r\r     Securities and Exchange Commission v. First Zurich National U.S. A, LLC, et\r     al., Civil Action No. 98-CV-29D  (USDC Wy.) \r\r          The Commission today filed an amended complaint and obtained emergency\r     relief in a pending action involving an affinity fraud largely targeting\r     African Americans.  The Commission alleges that the defendants are offering\r     and selling stock in Compunics 139, Inc. (Compunomics) and First Zurich\r     National USA, LLC (First Zurich) and making false claims to investors\r     about the potential value of Compunomics\ stock, as well as failing to\r     disclose that First Zurich cannot legally operate as a bank.  Judge William\r     F. Downes issued a temporary restraining order and other relief against\r     Paul D. Catchings (Catchings), who is the president and chief executive\r     officer of Compunomics, and who was added as a defendant in the amended\r     complaint.  This civil action was originally filed by the Commission on\r     February 2, 1998 in the United States District Court for the District of\r     Wyoming [See, Litigation Release No. 15634, February 3, 1998].  \r\r          The amended complaint alleges that in soliciting persons to purchase\r     Compunomics\ stock, Catchings and Compunomics are falsely representing to\r     investors (some of whom have purchased Compunomics\ stock for as low as\r     $0.32 per share) that they will reap enormous profits when the stock begins\r     publicly trading in the near future at $10.00 per share.  The complaint\r     also alleges that they are falsely representing to investors that\r     Compunomics will soon be profitably operating a bank.    \r\r          The amended complaint alleges that in soliciting persons to acquire\r     stock in First Zurich, a Wyoming limited liability company and Compunomics\r     subsidiary (which Compunomics claims to be a global internet bank),\r     Catchings and the two companies are failing to disclose to investors that\r     First Zurich cannot legally operate as a bank.  The Office of the\r     Comptroller of the Currency has not granted a national bank charter to\r     First Zurich nor has the Wyoming State Banking Board authorized First\r     Zurich to conduct banking operations.  Moreover, First Zurich, as a Wyoming\r     limited liability company, is not permitted under Wyoming corporate law to\r     conduct banking operations.  \r\r          The amended complaint further alleges that Catchings, Compunomics and\r     First Zurich have, since approximately April 1995 to the present, sold\r     between $4 million and $5 million of Compunomics and First Zurich stock. \r     Between 1,000 and 2,000 persons have purchased Compunomics\ stock and at\r     least 400 persons have purchased First Zurich stock.  Sales and promotional\r     activities have been largely directed towards African Americans.  Public\r     sales meetings were held on a regular basis at Los Angeles area restaurants\r     from approximately April 1995 to April 1997 where the false claims were\r     made.  In July 1997, Compunomics\ former vice chairman and chief operating\r     officer addressed approximately 30,000 persons attending the Full Gospel\r     Baptist Fellowship conference in New Orleans.  Written materials approved\r     and authorized by Catchings repeating the false claims were disseminated\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     during the convention.  Also, sales materials containing false and\r     misleading information concerning Compunomics have been and, continue to be\r     posted on the internet.  \r          The amended complaint charges that the defendants have violated the\r     antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws -- Section 17(a) of the\r     Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of\r     1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. \r          The Commission has received substantial assistance in this case from\r     the California Department of Corporations, the Wyoming State Securities\r     Division and the Cheyenne, Wyoming office of the United States Postal\r     Inspection Service.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                       U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Ligitigation Release No. 15640 / February 12, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. AMERICAN INTERNET PARTNERS, INC.,\r     AMERICAN INTERNET PARTNERS SAN JOSE, CONNECTEL COMMUNICATIONS, INC., STEVEN\r     P. HEVELL, AND JIM D. JAMES, Civil Action No. 98-1014 CAS (C.D. Cal.)\r\r          The SEC announced that late yesterday it sued Steven P. Hevell and his\r     companies American Internet Partners, Inc., American Internet Partners San\r     Jose, ConnecTel Communications, Inc., and Jim D. James to stop an on-going\r     securities fraud.  The SEC obtained a Temporary Restraining Order and froze\r     the assets of the Defendants, who live in Orange County.  Hevell and his\r     other companies are already defendants in another SEC fraud case, SEC v.\r     MicroWest Industries, Inc., CV 97-9150 CAS, filed last September.  The SEC\r     filed both Complaints in federal district court in Los Angeles.\r\r          The Complaint alleges that from July 1997 until the SEC obtained the\r     Temporary Restraining Order, the Defendants raised over $1.06 million from\r     the sale of unregistered securities to at least 56 investors.  The\r     investors are unsophisticated and live throughout the country. \r     Furthermore, nearly 20 percent of the funds invested were retirement funds. \r     The Defendants told investors that their money would be used to purchase an\r     Internet service provider. The Complaint alleges that Defendants spent only\r     $300,000 on Internet service equipment but did not buy an Internet service\r     provider. The Complaint further alleges that Defendants misused most of the\r     investor funds.  Defendants told investors that their money would not be\r     used to pay sales commissions.  However, over half of the investor funds\r     ($558,000) were paid to independent sales agents for commissions.  In\r     addition, Defendants paid at least $76,000 to Hevell, the undisclosed\r     promoter of this alleged investment scheme.  Furthermore, Defendants\r     transferred $46,000 to a company in which Hevell has an interest. \r     Defendants also used at least $4,300 for Hevell s personal expenses,\r     including his cellphone and go-cart racing hobby.  Finally, the remaining\r     investor funds, approximately $76,000, were spent on operating expenses,\r     including rent and employee salaries and bonuses.\r\r          The Complaint seeks a preliminary injunction, permanent injunction and\r     disgorgement against AIP, AIP San Jose, Hevell, and James for violating\r     Sections 5 and 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder and against\r     ConnecTel for violating Section 17(a) of the Securities Act and Section\r     10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5.  The Court set the hearing on the\r     SEC s application for a preliminary injunction for Monday, February 23,\r     1998.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r\r     LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15641 / February 17, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. S. JIM FARHA, \r     Case No. 1:98CV00133 (D.C.C.)         \r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) announced that on\r     January 13, 1998 it filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for\r     the District of Columbia against S. Jim Farha  (Farha), a resident of\r     Wichita, Kansas, for violations of the anti-fraud provisions of the federal\r     securities laws, namely Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and\r     Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5\r     thereunder, arising out of his insider trading in the common stock of\r     Physician Corporation of America, a Florida-based health care provider\r     which was recently acquired.  Simultaneously with the filing of the SEC\s\r     lawsuit, Farha, with neither admitting nor denying the SEC\s allegations,\r     consented to a permanent injunction and agreed to pay a total of\r     $419,318.00 in disgorgement, pre-judgment interest and a civil penalty.  On\r     January 29, 1998, the Court entered a final judgment against Farha.\r\r          According to the SEC\s complaint, on March 22, 1995 Farha\r     misappropriated from a PCA insider material, non-public information\r     concerning an unfavorable quarterly earnings announcement for PCA scheduled\r     to be publicly released the next day.  The SEC alleges that Farha, with\r     knowledge of PCA\s unfavorable earnings announcement, sold certain of his\r     PCA stock holdings that same day.  On March 23, 1995, PCA issued its\r     announcement and PCA stock fell approximately 20% on heavy volume.  The SEC\r     contends that Farha avoided losses of over $186,000 through his sale of PCA\r     stock.  The SEC\s lawsuit further alleges that Farha began repurchasing PCA\r     stock on March 23, 1995 and the days thereafter at prices lower than that\r     at which he had previously sold.\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                                                       SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                                                                WASHINGTON, D.C.\r\r         Litigation Release No. 15642 / February 17, 1998\r\r         Securities and Exchange Commission v.Robert A. Foisie \r         Civil No. 98-CV-0420  (D.D.C.) (filed February 17, 1998)\r\r         On February 17, 1998, the Commission filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia\r         against Robert Foisie (Foisie).  The complaint alleges that Foisie, a resident of Old Saybrook, Connecticut, failed to file\r         thirty required forms reporting his securities ownership with the Commission, as required by the Securities Exchange Act of\r         1934 (Exchange Act), for securities transactions in his Stratton Oakmont brokerage account.  Specifically, Foisie failed to\r         file eight Schedules 13D, reporting acquisition of beneficial ownership of the common stock of seven issuers; sixteen\r         amendments to Schedule 13D, reporting changes in the information with respect to his beneficial ownership of the common stock\r         of eight issuers; two Forms 3, reporting holdings of two issuers, and four Forms 4, reporting changes in beneficial ownership\r         of two issuers.  The Commission seeks to enjoin Foisie from further violations of Sections 13(d) and 16(a) of the Exchange Act\r         of 1934 and Rules13d-1, 13d-2, 16a-2 and 16a-3 thereunder, and order him to pay a $25,000 civil penalty.  Simultaneously with\r         the filing of the Commission\s complaint, Foisie consented to the entry of a Final Judgment granting the relief sought by the\r         Commission and admitted that he had not filed the reports as described above.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                                                   ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                    UNITED STATES SECURITIES & EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15643 / February 18, 1998\r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION  v.  ENVIRONMENTAL CHEMICALS GROUP,\r     INC., CURTIS A. YOUNTS, JR., CALVIN SHENKIR, Jr., and CALVIN MOERBE, Civil\r     Action No. SA 96 CA 1319 (W.D. Texas, San Antonio Div.) \r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. CURTIS A. YOUNTS, JR., RONALD E.\r     HENDRIX and LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & COMPANY, SA 95 CA 1100 (OLG) (W.D. Texas,\r     San Antonio Div.) \r\r          The Securities and Exchange Commission (the Commission) announced\r     today that Judge Orlando Garcia of the United States District Court for the\r     Western District of Texas, San Antonio Division, entered an order requiring\r     the liquidation of a 1,171 acre ranch in Texas belonging to Curtis A.\r     Younts, Jr. ( Younts ) and/or Diane Younts, in satisfaction of the\r     Commission s judgment against Younts for  $668,268 in disgorgement and\r     civil penalties in SEC v. Younts, et al., and SEC v. Environmental\r     Chemicals Group, Inc., et al. \r\r          On December 13, 1997, the Court entered a Final Judgment by Consent\r     against Younts in SEC v. Younts, et al.  Pursuant to the terms of the\r     Consent, Younts agreed, among other things, to pay $600,000 in disgorgement\r     and civil penalties. Younts  Consent and the Court s Final Judgment\r     required him to make twelve quarterly payments of $50,000 over three years.\r\r\r          On January 31, 1997, Younts defaulted on his first  quarterly payment.\r     On March 4, 1997, the Commission filed an application for an Order to Show\r     Cause why Younts should not be held in civil contempt for failure to pay\r     Court ordered  disgorgement and civil penalties. On March 12, 1997, the\r     Court granted the Commission s application.  In response to the Court s\r     Order to Show Cause,  Younts alleged that he was financially incapable of\r     meeting his payment obligations.  The Commission alleged that Younts could\r     satisfy his obligations by liquidating his ranch located in Bell and Milam\r     Counties, Texas, and valued at over $773,000.\r\r          On January 22, 1998, the Court held a hearing to determine whether\r     Younts should be incarcerated for failure to meet his payment obligations.\r     At the conclusion of the Contempt hearing, the Court entered an Order,\r     based on an agreement between the parties, authorizing the appointment an\r     agent to oversee the liquidation of the ranch. The Court also imposed\r     $68,268 in prejudgment and postjudgment interest which, prior to Younts \r     default, had been waived.  On February 10, 1998, the Court issued an Order\r     appointing an equity receiver to sell the ranch by either public auction or\r     private sale. The ranch is currently Younts  primary residence. \r\r\r\r\r                                        - 2 -\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r          The Commission\s Complaint in SEC v. Younts, et al. alleged that\r     Younts, former president, chairman and chief executive officer of\r     Littlefield, Adams & Company (LFA) violated the antifraud, corporate\r     reporting and registration requirements of the federal securities laws by,\r     among other things, misappropriating more than $1.15 million from LFA and\r     engaging in various schemes and fraudulent accounting practices designed to\r     inflate artificially  LFA\s income and otherwise manipulate LFA\s stock\r     price.   For further information concerning SEC v. Younts, et al., see SEC\r     Litigation Release No. 14547, AAER No. 685 (June 27, 1995).  \r\r           The Commission\s Complaint in SEC v. Environmental Chemicals Group,\r     Inc., alleged that Younts, former president, chairman and chief executive\r     officer of Environmental Chemicals Group, Inc. ( EnChem ) violated the\r     antifraud, insider trading, corporate reporting and registration\r     requirements of the federal securities laws by, among other things, filing\r     periodic reports with the Commission and distributing press releases and\r     other materials that contained materially false and misleading\r     representations about the company\s revenues, product lines and business\r     prospects. For further information concerning SEC v. Environmental\r     Chemicals Group, Inc., et al., see SEC Litigation Release No. 15183\r     (December 11, 1996), AAER No. 862 (December 11, 1996).\r      \r\r\r       \r      \r      \r\r                                           \r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r          LITIGATION RELEASE NO. 15644 / February 18, 1998\r\r            SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION V. J. BRISTOW ANDERSON, BRADLEY F. BAHRET,\r            DEBORAH D. BAHRET, LISA R. BURGESS-PITTMAN,LINDA A. CONNOR, GEORGE L. GORE, JR., M.\r            LEON JENSEN, STEPHEN J. KATZ, AND CHARLES R. PERRY, JR., CIVIL ACTION FILE NO. 1:97-\r            2432-JEC\r\r            On December 10, 1997, the Honorable Julie E. Carnes, United States District Judge\r            for the Northern District of Georgia, entered orders of permanent injunction against\r            M. Leon Jensen ( Jensen ) of Duluth, Georgia and George Gore, Jr. ( Gore ) of Castle\r            Rock, Colorado. Gore is a former employee and Jensen is a former director of Paragon\r            Mortgage Corporation,a now defunct mortgage banking company, formerly headquartered\r            in Smyrna, Georgia.\r\r            Without admitting or denying the allegations set forth against them, Jensen and Gore\r            consented to judgments of permanent injunction enjoining them from violating Section\r            17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act\r            of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Disgorgement and civil penalties were ordered\r            with 1) Jensen consenting to pay $6,990 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest,\r            and $7,688 in civil penalties and 2) Gore consenting to pay $2,587 in disgorgement\r            and prejudgment interest, and $2,813 in civil penalties.\r\r            Litigation against defendant Bradley Bahret of Marietta, Georgia is continuing.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                                    ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                          SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15645 / February 18, 1998\r\r     Securities and Exchange Commission v. First Zurich National USA, LLC,\r     Compunomics 139, Inc. and Paul Douglas Catchings, Civil Action No. 98-CV-\r     29D (USDC WY)\r\r          On February 13, 1998, the United States District Court for the\r     District of Wyoming issued an order for civil contempt and arrest against\r     Paul Douglas Catchings (Catchings) individually, and as president and\r     Chief Executive Officer of Compunomics 139, Inc. (Compunomics), for\r     violating the Court\s temporary restraining orders of February 10, 1998\r     [See Litigation Release No. 15639, February 10, 1998], and February 3,\r     1998.  [See Litigation Release No. 15634, February 3, 1998]  The Court also\r     issued a preliminary injunction against First Zurich National USA, LLC\r     (First Zurich), Compunomics and Catchings in an action involving an\r     affinity fraud largely targeting African Americans.  The Court enjoined\r     each from violating the antifraud provisions of the Securities Act of 1933\r     and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  The Court also continued the\r     asset freeze of, and ordered an accounting of assets from, each defendant. \r     Finally, the Court appointed a special officer to take control of the\r     assets, accounts and property of First Zurich, Compunomics and Catchings. \r     This civil action was originally filed by the Commission on February 2,\r     1998, in the United States District Court for the District of Wyoming\r     against First Zurich and Compunomics.  The Commission filed an amended\r     complaint adding Catchings as an individual defendant on February 10, 1998.\r\r          The preliminary injunction was based on the Commission\s February 10,\r     1998, amended complaint, which alleges that in soliciting persons to\r     purchase Compunomics\ stock, Catchings and Compunomics are falsely\r     representing to investors (some of whom have purchased Compunomics\ stock\r     for as low as $0.32 per share) that they will reap enormous profits when\r     the stock begins publicly trading in the near future at $10.00 per share. \r     The complaint also alleges that they are falsely representing to investors\r     that Compunomics will soon be profitably operating a bank.    \r\r          The amended complaint alleges that in soliciting persons to acquire\r     stock in First Zurich, a Wyoming limited liability company and Compunomics\r     subsidiary (which Compunomics claims to be a global internet bank),\r     Catchings and the two companies are failing to disclose to investors that\r     First Zurich cannot legally operate as a bank.  The Office of the\r     Comptroller of the Currency has not granted a national bank charter to\r     First Zurich nor has the Wyoming State Banking Board authorized First\r     Zurich to conduct banking operations.  Moreover, First Zurich, as a Wyoming\r     limited liability company, is not permitted under Wyoming corporate law to\r     conduct banking operations.  \r\r          The amended complaint further alleges that Catchings, Compunomics and\r     First Zurich have, since approximately April 1995 to the present, sold\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c\r\r\r\r\r\r\r     between $4 million and $5 million of Compunomics and First Zurich stock. \r     Between 1,000 and 2,000 persons have purchased Compunomics\ stock and at\r     least 400 persons have purchased First Zurich stock.  Sales and promotional\r     activities have been largely directed towards African Americans.  Public\r     sales meetings were held on a regular basis at Los Angeles area restaurants\r     from approximately April 1995 to April 1997 where the false claims were\r     made.  In July 1997, Compunomics\ former vice chairman and chief operating\r     officer addressed approximately 30,000 persons attending the Full Gospel\r     Baptist Fellowship conference in New Orleans.  Written materials approved\r     and authorized by Catchings repeating the false claims were disseminated\r     during the convention.  Also, sales materials containing false and\r     misleading information concerning Compunomics have been, and continue to\r     be, posted on the internet.  \r\r          The amended complaint charges that the defendants have violated the\r     antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws -- Section 17(a) of the\r     Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of\r     1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. \r\r          The Commission has received substantial assistance in this case from\r     the California Department of Corporations, the Wyoming State Securities\r     Division and the Cheyenne, Wyoming office of the United States Postal\r     Inspection Service.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 2======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                   UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r\r     Litigation Release No. 15646 / February 19, 1998 \r\r     SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. VICTOR TEICHER, ROSS S. FRANKEL,\r     VICTOR TEICHER & CO. AND CARMEL PARTNERS, LP., 91 Civ. 1634(MP)\r       \r\r          On December 11, 1997, Victor Teicher and two entities, Victor Teicher\r     & Co. and Carmel Partners, LP, (the Teicher Defendants) were ordered, by\r     consent, to pay $982,594.14 in disgorgement, pre-judgment interest and\r     penalties.  The Teicher Defendants agreed to entry of the order, which also\r     enjoins them from future violations of Sections 10(b) and 14(e) of the\r     Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Rules 10b-5 and 14e-3 thereunder.\r\r          In the Commission\s lawsuit, filed in March 1991, Victor Teicher was\r     alleged to have purchased seven different stocks in 1986, while in\r     possession of non-public information (Allegheny International, Inc.,\r     American Brands, Inc., American Can, Inc., Avondale Mills, Inc.,\r     Westchester Financial Services, Co. and Warnaco, Inc., Revco, D.S. Inc.). \r     According to the complaint, the inside information was misappropriated from\r     three sources: a law firm (Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison), an\r     investment banking firm (Drexel Burnham & Lambert Inc.), and a broker-\r     dealer (Marcus Schloss & Co.).  Teicher, an investment manager, was alleged\r     to have obtained the non-public information from members of the so-called\r     Yuppie Five group of insider traders.  The Teicher Defendants agreed to\r     disgorge $265,400.44, representing the profits from the trading in the\r     seven securities.  The Teicher Defendants also agreed to pay pre-judgment\r     interest on the disgorgement amount of $498,713.57, and a civil penalty of\r     $218,480.13 pursuant to the Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984.  The\r     payments are due by December 22, 1997.  Teicher was previously tried and\r     convicted on criminal charges arising from the same trades.  (See\r     Litigation Releases Nos. 11915, November 18, 1988; 12800, March 8, 1991;\r     14109, June 4, 1992.)\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                              ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\x0c

b\r\r\r\r             SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION\r                      WASHINGTON, D.C.\r\rLitigation Release No. 15647 / February 19, 1998\r\rSecurities and Exchange Commission v. Inamed Corporation\rCivil No. 98-CV-00431  (D.D.C.) (filed February 18, 1998)\r\rOn February 18, 1998, the Commission filed a complaint in\rthe United States District Court for the District of\rColumbia against Inamed Corporation (Inamed).  The\rcomplaint alleges that Inamed, a medical products company\rwhose securities are quoted in the pink sheets, failed to\rmake available to the investing public current and accurate\rinformation about its financial condition and results of\roperation through the filing of periodic reports with the\rCommission as required by the Securities Exchange Act of\r1934 (Exchange Act).  Specifically, the complaint alleges\rthat Inamed has not filed its Annual Report on Form 10-K for\rthe fiscal year ended December 31, 1996 and a Notification\rof Late Filing with respect to that report. The Commission\rseeks to compel Inamed to file its delinquent periodic\rreports and enjoin Inamed from further violations of Section\r13(a) of the Exchange Act of 1934 and Rules 12b-25 and 13a-1\rthereunder.  Simultaneously with the filing of the\rCommission\s complaint, Inamed consented to the entry of a\rFinal Judgment granting the relief sought by the Commission\rand admitted that it had not filed the periodic reports as\rdescribed above.\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r\r                     ======END OF PAGE 1======\r\r
